revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Web|date=December 2016}} {{third-party|date=December 2016}} }}
{{Infobox website | name = Abbreviations.com | logo_size = 180px | logo = File:Top logo abbreviations com.png | logo_alt = | logo_caption = <!-- or: | logocaption = --> | screenshot = | collapsible = <!-- set as "on", "y", etc, otherwise omit/leave blank --> | collapsetext = <!-- collapsible area's heading (default "Screenshot"); omit/leave blank if collapsible not set --> | background = <!-- for collapsetext heading; default grey (gainsboro) --> | screenshot_size = <!-- default 300px --> | screenshot_alt = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://www.abbreviations.com}} | slogan = | commercial = Yes | type = [[Dictionary]] | registration = | language = [[English language|English]] | num_users = | content_license = <!-- or: | content_licence = --> | programming_language = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | author = STANDS4<!-- or: creator / authors / creators --> | editor = <!-- or: | editors = --> | launch_date = {{start date and age|2001|1|1}} | revenue = | alexa = <!-- {{increase}} {{steady}} {{decrease}} [http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/example.com ##] (US/Global MM/YYYY) --> | ip = | current_status = | footnotes = }} '''Abbreviations.com''' is an online [[abbreviation]]s dictionary whose domain was first registered on 2001.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.whois.com/whois/abbreviations.com|title=Whois abbreviations.com|website=www.whois.com|access-date=2016-12-04}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arHUCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA113&dq=%22Abbreviations.com%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjtr6v3o77RAhVI44MKHYZ8AS0Q6AEIMDAD#v=onepage&q=%22Abbreviations.com%22&f=false|title=Planning non existent dictionaries|last=Paulo|first=Silvestre, João|last2=Alina|first2=Villalva|publisher=Centro de Linguística - Universidade de Lisboa|year=|isbn=9789899866614|location=|pages=113|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref> The company was founded by Yigal Ben Efraim as part of STANDS4 LLC, which also operates Lyrics.com, Grammar.com and Symbols.com among other reference related websites.
As of 2016 the website includes nearly a million definitions that are classified by a large variety of categories from computing and the Web to governmental, military, medicine and more. The database is being built by contributing editors, who can sign up on the website and help expanding it by submitting new entries for inclusion. The website also offers its content to be freely used by third-parties through its open [[Application programming interface|APIs]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.programmableweb.com/api/abbreviations|title=Open Abbreviations API|website=www.programmableweb.com|access-date=2016-12-04}}</ref>
==Reception==
''Reference Reviews'' wrote a review for the site in 2013, stating that it "certainly has its place among the librarians' quick reference websites" but that " the authoritativeness of the site entries is not completely evident. There are no external references available to verify entry reliability. While I would recommend this site to all librarians, it would certainly be a cautionary recommendation."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kapranos|first=Aubrey|date=2013-06-07|year=|title=Abbreviations.com (review)|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/10.1108/RR-02-2013-0037|journal=Reference Reviews|volume=27|issue=5|pages=13–13|doi=10.1108/RR-02-2013-0037|issn=0950-4125|via=}}</ref> ''[[Choice: Current Reviews for Academic Libraries|Choice]]'' was also critical of the site, writing that "Unfortunately it falls short compared to other online and print sources" and noted that the site had errors, which they contributed to the site seeming to allow user generated content.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Abbreviations.com (review)|journal=Choice: Current Reviews for Academic Libraries|date=2007|volume=45|issue=4|page=599|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/225765050|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref>
===Awards and recognition===
In 2005 the website has been selected as one of the "101 Best Web Sites for Writers" by the American magazine [[Writer's Digest]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://writersdigest.com/101sites/categorysearch.asp?category=Just%20for%20fun&year_101=2005 |title=Writer's Digest 101 Best Websites for Writers |website=web.archive.org |access-date=2016-12-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051121165348/http://writersdigest.com/101sites/categorysearch.asp?category=Just+for+fun&year_101=2005 |archivedate=2005-11-21 }}</ref>
In 2010 the Abbreviations.com website has been selected as one of the "Best Free Reference Web Sites" by the [[American Library Association|ALA]]'s Reference and User Services Association.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ala.org/rusa/sections/mars/marspubs/marsbestfreewebsites/marsbestfree2010|title=2010 Twelfth Annual List|website=www.ala.org|access-date=2016-12-04}}</ref>
In 2015 the website's parent company STANDS4 has won the [[Red Herring (magazine)|Red Herring]] Top 100 Europe award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.redherring.com/events/red-herring-europe/2015-winners/|title=Red Herring 2015 Top 100 Europe winners|website=redherring.com|access-date=2016-12-04}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.abbreviations.com}} *[http://www.geektime.com/2013/06/29/what-does-that-symbol-stand-for-stands4-will-tell-you Review] at GeekTime *[http://killerstartups.com/review/abbreviations-com-finally-some-answers Review] at KillerStartups
[[Category:Online dictionaries]]

{{short description|Philippine mythical creature}} {{other uses}} {{Redirect|Tik Tik|the song by [[GFriend]]|Time for the Moon Night}} {{refimprove|date=September 2017}} {{rewrite|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox mythical creature | image = Aswang, common form.jpg | caption = An artist's sketch depicting the ''aswang'' | name = Aswang | grouping = A vampiric werebeast or cannibalistic human-like shape-shifter | Region = [[Visayas]], southern parts of [[Luzon]] and parts of [[Mindanao]]| equivalent = Tik-tik/ [[Wak-wak]] }}
An '''Aswang''' (or '''Asuwang''') is an [[umbrella term]] referring to a shapeshifting [[anito|evil spirit]] in [[Filipino folklore]], [[Manananggal|vampire]], a [[ghoul]], a [[mangkukulam|warlock/witch]], or different species of [[werebeast]]. It is the subject of a wide variety of myths and stories. Spanish colonists noted that the Aswang was the most feared among the mythical creatures of the Philippines, even in the 16th century.<ref name="Scott1994">{{cite book | last=Scott | first=W.H. | title=Barangay: Sixteenth-century Philippine Culture and Society | publisher=University of Hawaii Press | year=1994 | isbn=978-971-550-135-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=15KZU-yMuisC | access-date=18 July 2018 | page=}}</ref> The myth of the aswang is well known throughout the Philippines.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Tan |first=Michael |author-link=Michael Tan|title=Aswang! Aswang! |newspaper=Sunday Inquirer Magazine |date=2008-10-26 |url=http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/sim/sim/view/20081026-168528/Aswang-Aswang |deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081201094639/http://showbizandstyle.inquirer.net/sim/sim/view/20081026-168528/Aswang-Aswang |archivedate=2008-12-01}}</ref> It is especially popular in the [[Visayas]], southern parts of [[Luzon]], and parts of [[Mindanao]]. Other regional names for the aswang include "tik-tik", "wak-wak", "sok-sok" and "kling-kling".<ref name=Jordan/>
== About ==
Anthropologists postulate that the Aswang belief came from the myth-making of the Spaniards intent on keeping the population under control.<ref name="Nadeau">{{cite journal |last1=Nadeau |first1=Kathleen |title=Aswang and Other Kinds of Witches: A Comparative Analysis |journal=Philippine Quarterly of Culture and Society |date=December 2011 |volume=39 |issue=4 |pages=250–266 |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/23719118 |accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref> Through the ''[[encomienda]]'' system, a town was arranged into easy-to-manage layers, and those who lived too far away were labelled ''tulisans'' (dissenters).{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} To frighten the Filipinos and discourage mobility, stories of ''Aswangs'' living on the outskirts of the forests were spread in towns to keep everyone in groups and maintain control.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/scitech/technology/535657/the-aswang-diaspora-why-philippine-lower-myths-continue-to-endure/story/|title=The Aswang Diaspora: Why Philippine lower myths continue to endure|last=Montenegro|first=Bea|date=4 September 2015|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.aswangproject.com/aswang-in-capiz/|title=The truth about the ASWANG in Capiz|last=Clark|first=Jordan|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/supreme/2015/05/30/1460087/theres-aswang-terrorizing-mindanao-and-yes-please-take-seriously|title=There’s an ‘aswang’ terrorizing Mindanao – and yes, please take this seriously|last=Pineda|first=DLS|date=30 May 2015|website=Philippine Star|access-date=}}</ref>
Modern investigation links the prevalence of the aswang myth in the Capiz province of the Philippines to the genetic disease [[X-linked dystonia parkinsonism]] ([[X-linked dystonia parkinsonism|XDP]]) or [[X-linked dystonia parkinsonism|Dystonia of Panay]] ([[X-linked dystonia parkinsonism|Lubag Syndrome]]).<ref name="auto"/>
Quintessinal of these versions is the "bal-bal" or [[ghoul]] (''maninilong'' in [[Catanauan, Quezon]]), which replaces the cadaver with banana tree trunks after consumption. Aswang stories and definitions vary greatly from region to region and person to person, and no particular set of characteristics can be ascribed to the term. Another common and very popular version is the [[manananggal]] which are usually female.<ref>File:Carljames|thumbnail</ref>
== Appearance and activities == The wide variety of descriptions in the aswang stories makes it difficult to settle upon a fixed definition of aswang appearances or activities. However, several common themes that differentiate aswangs from other mythological creatures do emerge: Aswangs are typically described as [[Shapeshifting|shape-shifters]].<ref name="Nadeau"/> Stories recount aswangs living as regular townspeople that are quiet, shy and elusive. At night, they transform into creatures such as a bat, bird (usually a crow), wild boar, black cat, or most often, a big black dog.
They love to eat unborn fetuses and small children, favoring livers and hearts. Some have long [[proboscis]]es, which they use to suck the children out of their mothers' wombs when they are sleeping in their homes. Some are so thin that they can hide themselves behind a bamboo post. They are fast and silent. Some also make noises, like the Tik-Tik, (the name was derived from the sound it produces) which are louder the farther away the aswang is, to confuse its potential victim; and the Bubuu, an aggressive kind of aswang that makes a sound of a laying hen at midnight. They may also replace their live victims or stolen [[cadaver]]s with [[doppelganger]]s made from tree trunks or other plant materials. This facsimile will return to the victim's home, only to become extremely sick and then die. An aswang will also have bloodshot eyes, the result of staying up all night searching for houses where [[funeral|wakes]] are held to steal the bodies.
Aswangs are physically much more like humans at daytime; they only change their appearance at night when they feel they are hungry. It has been said that if an aswang married a human, upon their wedding, his or her mate would become an aswang as well but rarely can they reproduce. The couple may hunt together at night but will most often go in separate directions, either to avoid quick detection or because they do not like to share their food.
== Behavior == Unlike [[vampires]] and other similar creatures, they are not harmed by sunlight. They are daywalkers. Aswangs can also be befriended, they can talk to you like any normal human: they laugh and/or cry, get angry/sad, get hurt/humiliated and feel shy and envious. These creatures do not harm their friends and neighbors, and were said to be exempted from their target victims for food, hence the [[Filipino language|Filipino]] saying, "Mas mabuti ang aswang kaysa sa isang magnanakaw" (English: "An aswang is better than a thief").
They search for food in faraway places that it would not be too obvious for them. Aswangs are said to be vulnerable during daytime because during that time they do not have the excessive superhuman strength that they have in their nighttime prowl (aswangs only transform at night because they believe that God is sleeping). When people know of their identity, they are hunted down and killed immediately.
== Countermeasures against aswangs == Like vampires, aswangs are repelled or killed by using garlic, salt and religious artifacts/weapons (e.g. [[Holy water]], [[crucifix]], [[rosary]], prayers and religious verses). They are also killed using a whip made entirely of a stingray's tail ([[buntot pagi]]), which may also be used to repel the creature (aswangs are said to be scared of the sound made by the whip's cord slashing through the air). It is also said that they cannot step on holy consecrated ground (i.e. churches, mosques, temples, etc.). [[Decapitation]] is also a way to destroy an aswang.
Certain [[agimat]]s (native Philippine amulets) and special prayers posted on doors and entrances may also repel aswangs. A good example of which is the red and black bead bracelets worn by newborn babies.
It is said that to spot an aswang at daytime, look straight at their eyes. The person in front of you is an aswang if your reflection is upside-down. Another way of knowing is looking in a ''tuwad'' manner; that is, bending over and looking at the person from between your legs, upside-down. The person is an aswang if the image of the person is different. It is said that a person without a [[philtrum]] is an aswang. Hintura is a kind of oil made by [[albularyo]]s, used to detect if an aswang is near the premises. It is said that the oil will boil and bubble if an aswang is near.
== References in popular culture == {{unreferenced section|date=November 2016}} * ''[[Surviving Evil]]'' (also known as ''Evil Island'') is a 2009 horror film directed and written by Terence Daw, starring [[Billy Zane]], [[Christina Cole]], [[Natalie Mendoza]] and [[Louise Barnes]], where documentary filmmakers travel to a Philippine island only to discover that a colony of shape shifting, carnivorous aswang inhabit the island. * Aswang, specifically the "Tiktik", are one of the different breeds of Wesen (werebeast) and the main antagonist in the season 3, episode 14 ("Mother Dearest") of the NBC TV series [[Grimm (TV series)|''Grimm'']]. Detectives Nick Burkhardt and Hank Griffin and police Sergeant Drew Wu fought off an aswang which tried to suck the fetus out of a pregnant woman. * In a 2013 [[ABS-CBN]] TV series [[Juan dela Cruz (TV series)|''Juan dela Cruz'']], aswangs are the main antagonist which are being hunted by the protagonist Juan, who is half-aswang himself. * A type of aswang called the "Abuak" is featured in a 2011 [[Aswang (2011 film)|Filipino film of the same name]]. Abuak can transform from human to a raven-like creature that can fly and move underground as it stalks its victim. * [[Aswang (1994 film)|''Aswang'']] is a 1994 Filipino film in which a young woman agrees to marry a rich man. They live in a mansion together with his mother, who is the aswang. * An aswang is depicted as vampire-like creature in the ''Antagontists'' supplement to the new ''[[World of Darkness]]'' tabletop RPG game. * An aswang character appears in the fourth issue of comedy/horror webcomic ''Fantastic Crap Comics''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fantasticcrapcomics.com/?page_id=1212|title=Fantastic Crap Comics, Issue 4, cover!!! – Fantastic Crap Comics|website=www.fantasticcrapcomics.com|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=November 2016}} * Lynda Barry's "One! Hundred! Demons!" <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.drawnandquarterly.com/one-hundred-demons|title=One! Hundred! Demons!|publisher=|accessdate=17 July 2018}}</ref> includes a story of a grandmother threatening her with "the aswang." * An aswang is featured in the sixth episode of the Canadian TV show ''[[Lost Girl]]'', and is portrayed as a relatively harmless scavenger Fae. * Season 11, episode 3 of ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' ("Blood Moon") included a reference to the aswang, a hybrid cross between a vampire & werewolf. * The aswang myth is featured in ''[[The Forbidden Room (2015 film)|The Forbidden Room]]''.<ref name="Patches 2015">{{cite web |url=http://grantland.com/hollywood-prospectus/dreaming-bigger-cracking-the-forbidden-room-guy-maddins-inception-like-genre-explosion/|title=Dreaming Bigger: Cracking ‘The Forbidden Room,’ Guy Maddin’s ‘Inception’-like Genre Explosion|author=Matt Patches|date=2 February 2015|website=[[Grantland]]|publisher=[[ESPN]]|access-date=29 January 2017|quote=But that little contradiction in the Aswang myth from the Philippines is: Sometimes you turn into another vampire that bites other people, and sometimes you just decay into a banana. A blackened, but redolently sweet banana.}}</ref> * An aswang is the primary antagonist in the ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]'' spin-off novel ''Supernatural: Fresh Meat''. * Aswangs are also featured in the 2002 film ''[[Spirit Warriors: The Shortcut]]'' where they are described as hostile creatures in the dark world. * The [[Face Off (TV series)|''Face Off'']] episode "Bloodsuckers" featured Niko Gonzalez working on an aswang design. * In the 2013 first-person shooter game [[Shadow Warrior (2013 video game)|''Shadow Warrior'']], "Aswang Hunger" is an unlockable ability which allows the player to steal health points from enemies. * In the 2016 survival horror game ''[[Nightfall: Escape]]'', "Aswang" is one of the main antagonists. The Filipino horror game also featured similar creatures from [[Philippine mythology]]. * Aswang is a high level notorious monster in the 2017 game ''[[Final Fantasy XIV: Stormblood]]'', and is portrayed as a [[pterosaur]]. *In ''Code of Honor'', a short story written by [[Melissa de la Cruz]] in the 2018 anthology, "A Thousand Beginnings and Endings", the main character is a young philippine girl thinks that she and her late mother are Aswangs, but after moving to New York and attend to the Duchane Institute, she discovers that she is in fact a Blue Blood, one of the fallen angels that joined Lucifer in his fight against God. * In the 2016 [[Vampariah_(film)|Vampariah]] film with a modern twist on the aswang (Philippines Vampire) legend.
== Documentary == * The Aswang is the subject of the 2011 feature-length documentary ''[[The Aswang Phenomenon]]''. The film explores the aswang folklore and its effects on Philippine society. The documentary was also the first to uncover the origin of why the [[Western Visayas|Western Visayan]] province of [[Capiz]] is suspected as the aswang's home.<ref name=Jordan>Clark, Jordan (2011) ''The Aswang Phenomenon'' Documentary, High Banks Entertainment Ltd. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ePhqoyLpXQ</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == *{{Cite news | last = Cruz | first = Neal | author-link = Neal Cruz | title = As I See It: Philippine mythological monsters | newspaper = Philippine Daily Inquirer | pages = | date = 2008-10-31 | url =http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20081031-169390/Philippine-mythological-monsters | postscript = <!--None--> }} *{{cite book | last = Eugenio | first = Damiana | authorlink = Damiana L. Eugenio | coauthors = | title = Philippine Folk Literature: The Legends | publisher = University of the Philippines Press | year = 2002 | location =Matt Asombrado Paculba City | pages =490 | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 971-542-357-4 }} *{{cite book | last = Ramos | first = Maximo D. | authorlink = Maximo Ramos | coauthors = | title = Creatures of Philippine Lower Mythology | publisher = University of the Philippines Press | year = 1971 | location = Quezon City | pages = | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 971-06-0691-3 }} *{{Cite news |last=Ocampo |first=Ambeth |author-link=Ambeth Ocampo |title=Looking Back: 'Aswang' and counter-insurgency |newspaper=Philippine Daily Inquirer |pages= |date=2010-02-16 |url=http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20100216-253598/Aswang-and-counter-insurgency |postscript=<!--None--> |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220054947/http://opinion.inquirer.net/inquireropinion/columns/view/20100216-253598/Aswang-and-counter-insurgency |archivedate=2010-02-20 |df= }} * {{YouTube|2ePhqoyLpXQ|The Aswang Phenomenon – Full Documentary on the Filipino Vampire}}

revision.comment: babylon software is not publicly traded - babylon LTD. is and it's not relevant to babylon software anymore.
revision.text:
{{Infobox software |name = Babylon |logo = Babylon logo.png |logo size = 200px |screenshot = Babylon (program).png |caption = Babylon version 10.0 |developer = Babylon Software Ltd. |ver layout = stacked |operating system = {{Plainlist| *[[Windows NT]] *[[Android 2.3]].3 and later<ref>{{cite web|title=Babylon Translator|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.babylon.translator|website=[[Google Play]]|publisher=[[Google]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> *[[iOS]] 5.1 or later<ref>{{cite web|title=iBabylon|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/ibabylon/id353952483|website=[[iTunes Store]]|publisher=[[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> *[[Windows Phone 8]] and [[Windows Phone 8.1|8.1]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Babylon Translator|url=https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/store/p/babylon-translator/9wzdncrfhxmz|website=[[Windows Store]]|publisher=[[Microsoft]]|accessdate=16 October 2016}}</ref> }} |genre = [[Dictionary]], [[machine translation|machine translator]], [[spell checker]], [[browser hijacker]] |license = [[Trialware]] |website = {{url|http://www.babylon-software.com}} |alexa = {{IncreaseNegative}} 234 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web |url = https://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/babylon-software.com |title = Babylon-software.com Site Info |publisher = [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate = 2014-04-01 }}</ref> }}
'''Babylon''' is a [[Dictionary-based machine translation|computer dictionary and translation]] program developed by the [[Israel]]i company Babylon Software Ltd. based in the city of [[Or Yehuda]]. The company was established in 1997 by the Israeli entrepreneur Amnon Ovadia. Its [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] took place ten years later. It is considered a part of Israel's [[Download Valley]],<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/business/.premium-1.542896 Game over in Download Valley?] Haaretz, Inbal Orpaz, Orr Hirschauge, 22 August 2013</ref><ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304547704579563281761548844 Conduit Diversifies Away From 'Download Valley'] Wall Street Journal, Orr Hirschauge, updated 15 May 2014</ref> a cluster of software companies monetizing "free" software downloads through [[adware]]. Babylon includes in-house proprietary dictionaries, as well as community-created dictionaries and glossaries. It is a tool used for translation and conversion of currencies, measurements and time, and for obtaining other contextual information. The program also uses a [[text-to-speech]] agent, so users hear the proper pronunciation of words and text. Babylon has developed 36 English-based proprietary dictionaries in 21 languages. In 2008–2009, Babylon reported earnings of 50 million [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]] through its collaboration with [[Google]].
Between 2010 and 2013, Babylon became infamous for demonstrating questionable behavior typical of malware: A ''Babylon Toolbar'' bundled with Babylon and other software, has been widely identified as a [[browser hijacker]] that is very easy to install inadvertently and unnecessarily difficult to remove.<ref name="Babylon Search Hijacker" /><ref name="Remove Babylon Search Toolbar" /><ref name="Come-Uppance" /><ref name="Getting rid of Babylon" /> This eventually lead to Google terminating its agreement with Babylon Ltd. in 2013.<ref name="Google says enough!" />
==History== In 1995, [[Israel]]i entrepreneur Amnon Ovadia began a project for an online English–[[Hebrew Language|Hebrew]] dictionary which would not interrupt the reading process. As a result, Babylon Ltd. was founded in 1997 and launched the first version of Babylon. On 25 September 1997, the company filed a patent for text recognition and translation.<ref name="EKsIAAAAEBAJ">{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/about?id=EKsIAAAAEBAJ |title=Recognition and translation system |work = [[Google Patents]] |publisher=Google |accessdate=16 September 2011}}</ref> In 1998, a year following its launch date, Babylon had two million users, mostly in Germany and Brazil,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/tech/log/1999/11/02/babylon/index.html |title=Babble on |publisher=Salon Media Group, Inc |date=2 November 1999 |accessdate=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213181936/http://www.salon.com/tech/log/1999/11/02/babylon/index.html |archivedate=13 February 2010 |df=dmy }}</ref> growing from 420,000 to 2.5 million users in the course of that year. In the same year, [[Formula Systems]], headed by [[Dan Goldstein]], acquired Mashov Computers and became the largest shareholder in the company. By 2000, the product had over 4 million users. In the spring of 2000, Babylon Ltd. failed to raise $20 million in a private placement and lost [[Israeli new sheqel|NIS]] 15 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Blackburn |first=Nicky |title=By The Users of Babylon |accessdate=18 September 2011 |date=May 2002 |url=http://www.formulavision.com/News-innews/INNEWS-19052002BABYLON.htm?gotobtn=7 |work=Jerusalem Post via Formula Vision |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711020346/http://www.formulavision.com/News-innews/INNEWS-19052002BABYLON.htm?gotobtn=7 |archivedate=11 July 2011 }}</ref> Further stress came with the collapse of the [[Dot-com bubble]]. In 2001, Babylon Ltd. continued shedding money, with the company costing its parent company Formula Vision NIS 4.7 million.<ref>[http://www.thestreet.com/tech/themarker/10011432.html Formula Vision lost NIS 33.6 million in 2001]. TheMarker.com (3 April 2002)</ref>
Since 2007, Babylon Ltd. ({{TASE|BBYL}}) has been a publicly traded company. Its [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] took place in February 2007; Israeli businessman [[Noam Lanir]] purchased controlling interests in the company for $10.5 million, sharing management with second majority shareholder [[Reed Elsevier]]<ref>Malichi, Asaf (12 August 2007) [http://www.ynet.co.il/english/articles/0,7340,L-3480305,00.htm Noam Lanir buys into Babylon], YNet</ref> and the Company founder Amnon Ovadia. According to [[Globes]] magazine in January 2011, Lanir received an offer for his stake from a foreign private equity fund that valued the company at [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]] 248 million (approximately 70 million dollars).<ref>{{cite news|last=Ackerman |first=Gwen |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-19/babylon-shareholder-gets-offer-for-majority-stake-globes-says.html |title=Babylon Shareholder gets offer for majority stake, Globes says |publisher=Bloomberg |date=19 January 2011 |accessdate=16 September 2011}}</ref>
In 2008–2009, Babylon reported earnings of NIS 50 million through its collaboration with Google. In 2010, Google Ireland signed an extended cooperation agreement with Babylon to provide it with online search and pay-per-click advertising services.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000610889&fid=1725 Babylon extends deal with Google], Globes, 26 December 2010</ref>
In 2011, Babylon was named the seventh most popular website in Libya, the eighth in Algeria and the eleventh in Tunisia.<ref>Solomon, Shoshanna (11 December 2011) [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-11/babylon-says-arab-world-brazil-to-boost-language-software-sales.html Israel’s Babylon Says Arab World to Boost Sales of Translation Software]. bloomberg.com</ref>
According to [[Globes]] magazine, Noam Lanir, who acquired control of Babylon for NIS 20 million, made a paper profit of NIS 200 million on his investment in 2012.<ref name="globes.co.il">Tsipori, Tali (19 April 2012) [http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000742428&fid=1725 Noam Lanir makes NIS 200m profit on Babylon]. globes.co.il</ref>
According to Alexa, Babylon's website was once ranked 45th most popular website in the world.<ref name="globes.co.il"/> It is now ranked 494th.
==Product features== A single click on any text using the right mouse button or combination of the right mouse button and a keyboard modifier, and the Babylon window appears providing a translation and definition of the clicked term.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = [[PC World (magazine)|PC World]] | year = 2001 | volume = 19 | issue = 4–6 | pages = 123 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Huber | first = Jeffrey T | last2 = Boorkman |first2=Jo Anne | last3 = Blackwell |first3=Jean | title = Introduction to reference sources in the health sciences | year = 2008 | publisher = Neal-Schuman Publishers | isbn = 978-1-55570-636-4 | page = 127 }}</ref> Babylon is a tool used for translation and conversion of currencies, measurements and time, and for obtaining other contextual information. Babylon has a patented{{Specify|date=December 2012}} [[optical character recognition|OCR]] technology and a single-click activation that works in any [[Microsoft Windows]] application, such as [[Microsoft Word]], [[Microsoft Outlook]], [[Microsoft Excel]], [[Internet Explorer]] and [[Adobe Reader]]. When activated, Babylon opens a small popup window that displays the translation or definition.To solve the incompatibility problem of Babylon OCR browsers extension; users can benefit from Capture2Text free app version 3.9 (only 3.9v) which is compatible with Babylon 8 or another version. While dragging its capture box in any text from any browsers then a pop-up box appears and Babylon could easily grasp it. Babylon provides full text [[translation]], full [[Web page]] and full document translation in many languages and supports integration with [[Microsoft Office]]. Babylon enables the translation of [[Microsoft Word document]]s and [[plain text]] files. It offers results from a database of over 1,700 sources in over 75 languages.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Babylon – Simply Translate |url=http://www.babylon-software.com/about |publisher=Babylon Ltd |accessdate=18 September 2011 |df=dmy }}{{dead link|date=December 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
===Dictionaries and encyclopedias=== Babylon includes its in-house proprietary dictionaries, community-created dictionaries and glossaries ([[User-generated content|UGC]]), which include general and technical dictionaries, language and monolingual dictionaries, thesauri, encyclopedias and lexicons in a multitude of languages. They are indexed in 400 categories covering the arts, business, computers, health, law, entertainment, sports and so on.<ref>[http://www.babylon-software.com/define/ Free Dictionary Lookup by Babylon]. Babylon-software.com (2 August 2001). Retrieved on 9 November 2010.</ref>
The program also uses a [[text-to-speech]] agent so users hear the proper pronunciation of words and text. Babylon Ltd. has developed 36 English-based proprietary dictionaries in 21 languages (English, Arabic, [[Simplified Chinese]], [[Traditional Chinese]], Czech, Danish, Dutch, French, German, Greek, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish and Turkish) that are free of charge to users of the software. These dictionaries comprise between 60,000 and 200,000 terms, phrases, acronyms and abbreviations and are enabled with a morphological engine which facilitates recognition of all inflected forms of single words and phrases, provides all forms of terms that include prefixes and extensions and supplies a solution for all formats of writing. Babylon's [[Linguistic]] Department is responsible for the extensive content and information database which is a significant component of Babylon's Product.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jobs-israel.com/content.aspx?Category=605 |title=Babylon – There's Nothing Like Experience |first=Shuki |last=Stauber |publisher=Jobs-israel.com |accessdate=16 September 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402121052/http://www.jobs-israel.com/content.aspx?Category=605 |archivedate=2 April 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Malware issues== [[File:Babylon malware installer.png|thumb|Installer window from Download.com during the controversy with [[Nmap]]. After clicking on the green button, it installs the Babylon Toolbar, which hijacks the user's web browser.<ref>[http://insecure.org/news/download-com-fiasco.html Download.com Caught Adding Malware to Nmap & Other Software] insecure.org 27 June 2012</ref>]] On 7 August 2010, Microsoft antivirus products identified the software application as [[adware]] (identified as "Adware: Win32/Babylon") due to potentially intrusive behavior.<ref>{{cite web | title = Definition change log for version 1.87.1429.0 | url = https://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/definitions/whatsnew.aspx?RequestVersion=1.87.1429.0&Release=Released&Package=AM | work = Malware Protection Center& | publisher = Microsoft | date = 7 August 2010 | accessdate = 11 August 2010 }}</ref> Sixteen days later, on 23 August 2010, Microsoft announced that Babylon Ltd. had modified the program and that it was no longer categorized as adware.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.microsoft.com/security/portal/threat/encyclopedia/entry.aspx?Name=Adware%3aWin32%2fBabylon&ThreatID=152824 | title = Adware:Win32/Babylon | work = Malware Protection Center | date = 11 August 2010 | accessdate = 23 August 2010 | publisher = [[Microsoft]] }}</ref>
In 2011, [[Download.com]] started bundling the Babylon Toolbar with open-source packages such as [[Nmap]]. [[Gordon Lyon]], the developer of Nmap, criticized the decision.<ref>[https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/12/09/download_nmap_toolbar_row_latest/ Download.com sorry for bundling Nmap with crapware] The Register 9 December 2011</ref><ref>[http://nakedsecurity.sophos.com/2011/12/06/popular-security-tool-nmap-at-the-middle-of-a-security-brouhaha/ Popular network tool Nmap in CNET security brouhaha] ''Naked Security'' 6 December 2011</ref> The vice-president of Download.com, Sean Murphy, released an apology: "The bundling of this software was a mistake on our part and we apologize to the user and developer communities for the unrest it caused."<ref>[http://download.cnet.com/8301-2007_4-57338809-12/a-note-from-sean-regarding-the-download.com-installer/ A note from Sean regarding the Download.com Installer] Download.com 7 December 2011</ref>
In 2012 the Babylon search toolbar was identified as a [[browser hijacker]] that, while very easy to install inadvertently, is unnecessarily difficult to remove afterwards.<ref name="Babylon Search Hijacker">{{cite web |url = http://www.im-infected.com/hijacker/babylon-search-hijacker.html|title=Babylon Search Hijacker|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=7 November 2012|publisher = im-infected.com}}</ref><ref name="Remove Babylon Search Toolbar">{{cite web | url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2418379,00.asp | title=How to Remove Babylon Search Toolbar | work=[[PC Magazine]] |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] | date=2 May 2013 | accessdate=19 August 2013 | last=Rashid |first=Fahmida}}</ref><ref name="Come-Uppance">{{cite news|title=Babylon's Come-Uppance|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2013/10/30/babylons-come-uppance/|accessdate=24 November 2013|newspaper=[[Jewish Business News]]|date=30 October 2013}}</ref> The toolbar is listed as an unwanted application by anti-spyware software such as [[Stopzilla]] or [[Spybot – Search & Destroy]].<ref>[http://www.pcrisk.com/removal-guides/6754-instructions-to-remove-babylon-toolbar What is Babylon Toolbar and how to remove it?] pcrisk.com 9 July 2012</ref> Many users, trying to uninstall Babylon, have searched for help on different support forums.<ref>[http://www.itbusinessedge.com/blogs/from-under-the-rug/lesson-learned-the-hard-way-pay-attention-to-the-source-of-your-downloads.html Lesson Learned the Hard Way: Pay Attention to the Source of Your Downloads] Don Tennant, IT Business Edge, 11 September 2012</ref> The toolbar tends to install itself onto computers as an add-on with other software and changes users' home page to the Babylon search engine, adds the search engine to the computer and sets itself as the default.<ref name="Getting rid of Babylon">Lee, Jay (25 July 2012) [http://blog.chron.com/helpline/2012/07/getting-rid-of-babylon/ Getting rid of Babylon], The Houston Chronicle</ref> It changes browser preferences such as the user's home page and search engine, changes that can be very difficult to reverse.<ref>[http://techtalk.pcpitstop.com/2012/10/11/kill-zombie-babylon-and-fbi-virus-dead/#comment-27533 Remove FBI & Babylon Zombie Virus] PCPitstop.com, author Steve Hogan, 11 October 2012</ref><ref>Brinkmann, Martin (17 August 2011) [http://www.ghacks.net/2011/08/17/how-to-uninstall-the-babylon-toolbar-completely/ How To Uninstall The Babylon Toolbar Completely], ghacks.net.</ref>
On 29 October 2013, [[Google]] notified Babylon that it did not intend to renew its cooperation agreement between the two companies, which terminated on 30 November 2013. Google said that complaints had been received from [[Google Chrome]] users, claiming that the Babylon toolbar damages the browser's user experience. According to Babylon, Google may have reconsidered the decision during 2014.<ref name="Google says enough!">[https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/10/30/babylon-google-idUSL5N0IK24420131030 Shares in Israel's Babylon dive as Google ends contract] Reuters, 30 October 2013.</ref>
==See also== * [[Comparison of machine translation applications]] * [[Download Valley]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.babylon-software.com/products/babylon/}}

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Inherit]] (link changed to [[Inheritance]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
In '''''Carelse v Estate De Vries''''', an important case in [[South African succession law]], Carelse was [[seduction|seduced]], on the promise of [[marriage]], by the deceased (who was already married with children). Carelse and the deceased continued their relationship, which produced seven children, before the deceased died [[intestate]].
At that time, the [[Intestate succession|Intestate Succession]] Act said that [[illegitimate child]]ren could not [[Inheritance|inherit]] from their deceased parents. The [[court of law|court]] held, however, that this was no longer the proper position, and awarded [[child support|maintenance]] to the children. Although the deceased died intestate, the principle is the same for persons who die [[testacy|testate]].
== See also == * [[South African succession law]]
== References == * ''Carelse v Estate de Vries'' (1906) 23 SC 532.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:South African case law]] [[Category:1906 in South African law]] [[Category:1906 in case law]]
{{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

revision.text:
{{primary sources|date=October 2018}} {{refimprove|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Chicken Soup for the Soul | logo = | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = June 28, 1993{{cite web|url=http://www.chickensoup.com/cs.asp?cid=about|title=What is Chicken Soup for the Soul?|work=chickensoup.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}} | founder = [[Jack Canfield]][http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.jc Jack Canfield biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708144206/http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.jc |date=July 8, 2011 }} at official website and [[Mark Victor Hansen]][http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.mvh Mark Victor Hansen biography] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708144209/http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.mvh |date=July 8, 2011 }} at official website | location_city = [[Cos Cob, Connecticut|Cos Cob]], [[Connecticut]], USA[http://www.chickensoup.com/cs.asp?cid=contact Contact page] at official website |area_served = Worldwide | key_people = William J. Rouhana, Jr.[http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.wjr William J. Rouhana, Jr. biography] at official website
(Chairman & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])
Amy Newmark[http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=new.bio.an Amy Newmark biography] at official website
(Publisher) | industry = Publishing
Licensing
Internet
Consumer packaged goods
Entertainment | homepage = [http://www.chickensoup.com ChickenSoup.com] }} '''Chicken Soup for the Soul''' is a publishing, consumer goods and media company based in Cos Cob, CT. It is known for the ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' series of books. The first book, like most subsequent titles in the series, consisted of inspirational true stories about ordinary people's lives. The book became a major best-seller and something of a social phenomenon. Today Chicken Soup for the Soul Publishing, LLC continues to publish about a dozen{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=sr_pg_1?rh=n%3A283155%2Ck%3Achicken+soup+for+the+soul%2Cp_n_feature_browse-bin%3A2656022011%2Cp_lbr_books_series_browse-bin%3AChicken+Soup+for+the+Soul&sort=date-desc-rank&keywords=chicken+soup+for+the+soul&ie=UTF8&qid=1410307428|title=Amazon.com: chicken soup for the soul - Chicken Soup for the Soul / Paperback: Books|work=amazon.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}} new books per year. The company has branched out into other categories such as food,{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2123304,00.html|title=Pop Chart|date=10 September 2012|work=TIME.com|accessdate=23 February 2015|first=Kayla|last=Webley}} pet food,{{cite web|url=http://www.chickensoupforthepetloverssoul.com|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul|work=chickensoupforthepetloverssoul.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}} and television programming.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/alcon-entertainment-prescribing-chicken-soup-for-the-soul-218920141.html|title=Alcon Entertainment Prescribing 'Chicken Soup for the Soul' -- LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8, 2013 /PRNewswire/ --|author=Alcon Entertainment|date=8 August 2013|work=prnewswire.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://video.pbs.org/video/2365301258/|title=Video: Chicken Soup for the Soul : Food and Family - Watch PBS Specials Online - PBS Video|work=PBS Video|accessdate=23 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224000939/http://video.pbs.org/video/2365301258/|archivedate=24 February 2015|df=}} ==History== Motivational speakers [[Jack Canfield]] and [[Mark Victor Hansen]] collaborated on the first ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' book, compiling inspirational, true stories they had heard from their audience members. Many of the stories came from members of the audience of their inspirational talks. The book was rejected by major publishers in New York but accepted by a small, self-help publisher in Florida called HCI.{{Cite book|asin=161159913X|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul 20th Anniversary Edition: All Your Favorite Original Stories Plus 20 Bonus Stories for the Next 20 Years: Jack Canfield, Mark Victor Hansen, Amy Newmark: 9781611599138: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}} After the success of the first book, Canfield and Hansen, with HCI, published additional, similar ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/search?qt=worldcat_org_all&q=chicken+soup+for+the+soul|title=Results for 'chicken soup for the soul' [WorldCat.org]|work=worldcat.org|accessdate=23 February 2015}} Later, they published ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' books for specific demographics, such as ''Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul'', which came out in 1997{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/chicken-soup-for-the-teenage-soul/oclc/733779771&referer=brief_results|title=Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul|work=worldcat.org|accessdate=23 February 2015}} and was a major best-seller.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/99/08/22/bsp/paperadvicecompare.html|title=Independents/Chain Bestseller List|work=nytimes.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}} New ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' titles and sequels to existing books have been published on a regular basis since the first book came out in 1993. As of late 2013, the series included more than 200 titles.{{cite web|url=http://www.chickensoup.com/newsroom.asp?cid=about.facts|title=Facts & Figures|work=chickensoup.com|accessdate=23 February 2015}} In 2008, the founders, Jack Canfield and Mark Victor Hansen, sold the company to a new ownership group led by William J. Rouhana and Robert D. Jacobs.[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20090202/11989-serving-up-a-new-chicken-soup-.html Serving Up A New Chicken Soup], ''Publishers Weekly'', 2 February 2002. Since then all new titles have been published by Chicken Soup for the Soul Publishing, LLC and distributed by [[Simon & Schuster]]. Under the new ownership group, Chicken Soup for the Soul has expanded into other products besides books. The company markets pet foods under the brand Chicken Soup for the Pet Lover's Soul and a line of soups, sauces and other prepared foods{{cite web|url=http://www.chickensoup.com/foods/|title=Home - Chicken Soup for the Soul Foods|work=chickensoup.com|accessdate=23 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150227065443/http://www.chickensoup.com/foods/|archivedate=27 February 2015|df=}} under the brand Chicken Soup for the Soul. In 2009, author [[Adeline Lee Zhia Ern]] was found to have plagiarized the story "Happiness" by Sarah Provençal from Jack Canfield's ''Chicken Soup for the Teenage Soul IV''.[http://www.silverfishbooks.com/adeline_apology.html Adeline Lee's apology on Silverfish Books website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108110616/http://www.silverfishbooks.com/adeline_apology.html |date=January 8, 2010 }} In 2013, the company announced plans to produce a television series and movie with [[Alcon Entertainment]]. Chicken Soup for the Soul has produced television programming with other partners, including [[PBS]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=egaOwgEH6OE|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul: Food & Family - August 2014 on PBS|date=3 July 2014|work=YouTube|accessdate=23 February 2015}} Chicken Soup for the Soul Entertainment now owns owns Screen Media Ventures, LLC, a leading global independent television and film distribution company, and Popcornflix, an ad-based online video service. ==Awards== The original series held a spot on the New York Times Best Seller list continuously from 1994 - 1998.{{cite web|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul Awards, Announcements, and Recognition|url=http://original.chickensoup.com/cs.asp?cid=awards|website=Chicken Soup for the Soul|publisher=Chicken Soup for the Soul Publishing, LLC|accessdate=11 March 2018}} Chicken Soup for the Soul: What I Learned From the Dog was named "Best Anthology" of 2010 by the Dog Writers Association of America.{{cite web|title=Chicken Soup for the Soul Awards, Announcements, and Recognition|url=http://original.chickensoup.com/cs.asp?cid=awards|website=Chicken Soup for the Soul|publisher=Chicken Soup for the Soul Publishing, LLC|accessdate=11 March 2018}} ==See also== * [[List of Chicken Soup for the Soul books|List of ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' books]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.chickensoup.com Official website] * [http://www.hcibooks.com/c-3-chicken-soup-books.aspx Original publisher of the Best Selling ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' Books] * [http://series.simonandschuster.com/Chicken-Soup-for-the-Soul/books List of ''Chicken Soup for the Soul'' books at Simon and Schuster's website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Chicken Soup For The Soul}} [[Category:Media franchises introduced in 1993]] [[Category:Books about spirituality]] [[Category:Self-published books]] [[Category:Series of books]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2009}} {{ProgLangCompare}} [[List comprehension]] is a [[Syntax (programming languages)|syntactic]] construct available in some [[programming language]]s for creating a list based on existing lists. It follows the form of the mathematical ''[[set-builder notation]]'' (''set comprehension'') as distinct from the use of [[Map (higher-order function)|map]] and [[Filter (higher-order function)|filter]] functions. == Examples of list comprehension == === Boo === {{further2|[[Boo (programming language)|Boo]] for .NET/Mono}} List with all the doubles from 0 to 10 (exclusive) doubles = [i*2 for i in range(10)] List with the names of the customers based in [[Rio de Janeiro]] rjCustomers = [customer.Name for customer in customers if customer.State == "RJ"] === C# === {{further|C Sharp (programming language)#C.23 3.0 new language features|l1=C# 3.0 Language Integrated Query}} var ns = from x in Enumerable.Range(0,100) where x*x > 3 select x*2; The previous code is [[syntactic sugar]] for the following code written using lambda expressions: var ns = Enumerable.Range(0, 100) .Where(x => x*x > 3) .Select(x => x*2); === Ceylon === {{further2|[[Ceylon (programming language)|Ceylon]], [https://ceylon-lang.org/documentation/current/tour/comprehensions/ Ceylon comprehensions]}} Filtering numbers divisible by 3: value divisibleBy3 = { for (i in 0..100) if (i%3==0) i }; // type of divisibleBy3 is Iterable Multiple "generators": value triples = { for (x in 0..20) for (y in x..20) for (z in y..20) if (x*x + y*y == z*z) [x,y,z] }; // type of triples is Iterable === Clojure === {{further|List comprehension#Clojure}} An infinite lazy sequence: (for [x (iterate inc 0) :when (> (* x x) 3)] (* 2 x)) A list comprehension using multiple generators: (for [x (range 20) y (range 20) z (range 20) :when (== (+ (* x x) (* y y)) (* z z))] [x y z]) === CoffeeScript === {{further|CoffeeScript}} largeNumbers = (number for number in list when number > 100) === Common Lisp === {{further|Common Lisp}} List comprehensions can be expressed with the loop macro's collect keyword. Conditionals are expressed with if, as follows: (loop for x from 0 to 100 if (> (* x x) 3) collect (* 2 x)) === Cobra === {{further|Cobra (programming language)|l1=Cobra}} List the names of customers: names = for cust in customers get cust.name List the customers with balances: names = for cust in customers where cust.balance > 0 List the names of customers with balances: names = for cust in customers where cust.balance > 0 get cust.name The general forms: for VAR in ENUMERABLE [where CONDITION] get EXPR for VAR in ENUMERABLE where CONDITION Note that by putting the condition and expression ''after'' the variable name and enumerable object, editors and IDEs can provide [[autocompletion]] on the members of the variable. === Elixir === {{further|Elixir (programming language)|l1=Elixir}} for x <- 0..100, x * x > 3, do: x * 2 === Erlang === {{further|Erlang (programming language)|l1=Erlang}} L = lists:seq(0,100). S = [2*X || X <- L, X*X > 3]. === F# === {{further|F Sharp (programming language)|l1=F#}} Lazily-evaluated sequences: seq { for x in 0 .. 100 do if x*x > 3 then yield 2*x } Or, for floating point values seq { for x in 0. .. 100. do if x**2. > 3. then yield 2.*x } Lists and arrays: [ for x in 0. .. 100. do if x**2. > 3. then yield 2.*x ] [| for x in 0. .. 100. do if x**2. > 3. then yield 2.*x |] List comprehensions are the part of a greater family of language constructs called computation expressions. === Groovy === {{further|Groovy (programming language)|l1=Apache Groovy}} (0..100).findAll{ x -> x * x > 3 }.collect { x -> 2 * x } === Haskell === {{further|Haskell (programming language)|l1=Haskell}} [x * 2 | x <- [0 .. 99], x * x > 3] An example of a list comprehension using multiple generators: pyth = [(x,y,z) | x <- [1..20], y <- [x..20], z <- [y..20], x^2 + y^2 == z^2] === Io === By using Range object, Io language can create list as easy as in other languages: Range 0 to(100) asList select(x, x*x>3) map(*2) === ISLISP === {{further|ISLISP}} List comprehensions can be expressed with the for special form. Conditionals are expressed with if, as follows: (for ((x 0 (+ x 1)) (collect ())) ((>= x 100) (reverse collect)) (if (> (* x x) 3) (setq collect (cons (* x 2) collect)))) === Java 8 === {{further|Java (programming language)}} Java 8 introduces a new Streams API[https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/language/lambda_api_jdk8.html:jdk8_streams New and Enhanced APIs That Take Advantage of Lambda Expressions and Streams in Java SE 8], which includes the IntStream interface[https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/stream/IntStream.html:jdk8_intstream Interface IntStream] which allows operations like the following: List ns = IntStream.range(0,100) .filter(x -> x*x>3) .map(x -> x*2) // can be reduced with another operator or returned as a list: .boxed().collect(Collectors.toList()); === JavaScript === {{further|JavaScript}} Borrowing from Python, JavaScript has array comprehensions.[http://wiki.ecmascript.org/doku.php?id=harmony:array_comprehensions Array Comprehesions], ECMAScript Wiki Although this feature has been proposed for inclusion in the sixth edition [[ECMAScript]] standard, Mozilla is the only implementation that currently supports it. /* There is no "range" function in JavaScript's standard library, so the application must provide it using a Python-inspired generator function */ function* range(n) { for (var i = 0; i < n; i++) yield i; } [2 * x for (x of range(100)) if (x * x > 3)] === Julia === {{further|Julia (programming language)|l1=Julia}} Julia supports comprehensions using the syntax: y = [x^2+1 for x in 1:10] and multidimensional comprehensions like: z = [(x-5)^2+(y-5)^2 for x = 0:10, y = 0:10] === Mythryl === {{further|Mythryl}} s = [ 2*i for i in 1..100 where i*i > 3 ]; Multiple generators: pyth = [ (x,y,z) for x in 1..20 for y in x..20 for z in y..20 where x*x + y*y == z*z ]; === Nemerle === {{further|Nemerle}} $[x*2 | x in [0 .. 100], x*x > 3] === OCaml === {{further|OCaml}} ''OCaml supports List comprehension through OCaml Batteries''.[http://batteries.forge.ocamlcore.org/ OCaml Batteries Included] === Perl 6 === {{further|Perl 6}} my @s = ($_ * 2 if $_ ** 2 > 3 for 0 .. 99); === Python === {{further|Python syntax and semantics#Generators|l1=Python syntax and semantics: Generators}} [[Python (programming language)|Python]] uses the following syntax to express list comprehensions over finite lists: S = [2*x for x in range(100) if x**2 > 3] A '''generator expression''' may be used in Python versions >= 2.4 which gives [[lazy evaluation]] over its input, and can be used with [[generator (computer science)|generators]] to iterate over 'infinite' input such as the count generator function which returns successive integers: from itertools import count S = (2*x for x in count() if x**2 > 3) (Subsequent use of the generator expression will determine when to stop generating values). === R === {{further|R (programming language)|l1=R}} x = (0:100) S = 2 * x[x ^ 2 > 3] === Racket === {{further|Racket (programming language)|l1=Racket}} (for/list ([x 100] #:when (> (* x x) 3)) (* x 2)) An example with multiple generators: (for*/list ([x (in-range 1 21)] [y (in-range 1 21)] [z (in-range 1 21)] #:when (= (+ (* x x) (* y y)) (* z z))) (list x y z)) === Ruby === {{further|Ruby (programming language)|l1=Ruby}} (0..100).select { |x| x**2 > 3 }.map { |x| 2*x } === Scala === {{further|Scala (programming language)|l1=Scala}} Using the for-comprehension: val s = for (x <- 0 to 100; if x*x > 3) yield 2*x === Scheme === {{further|Scheme (programming language)|l1=Scheme}} List comprehensions are supported in Scheme through the use of the [[Scheme Requests for Implementation|SRFI]]-42 library.[http://srfi.schemers.org/srfi-42/srfi-42.html Scheme SRFI 42: Eager Comprehensions] (list-ec (: x 100) (if (> (* x x) 3)) (* x 2)) An example of a list comprehension using multiple generators: (list-ec (: x 1 21) (: y x 21) (: z y 21) (if (= (+ (* x x) (* y y)) (* z z))) (list x y z)) === SETL === {{further|SETL}} s := {2*x : x in {0..100} | x**2 > 3 }; === Smalltalk === ((1 to: 100) select: [ x | x squared > 3 ]) collect: [ x | x * 2 ] === Swift === // 0 2 4 6 ... 18 let timesTwo = (0..<10).map{ $0*2 } // Suppose isPrime: (Int) -> Bool a function that checks if its argument is a prime number let primeBelow100 = (0...100).filter(isPrime) === Visual Prolog === {{further|Visual Prolog}} S = [ 2*X || X = list::getMember_nd(L), X*X > 3 ] === Windows PowerShell === {{further|Windows PowerShell}} $s = ( 0..100 | ? {$_*$_ -gt 3} | % {2*$_} ) which is short-hand notation of: $s = 0..100 | where {$_*$_ -gt 3} | foreach {2*$_} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://rosettacode.org/wiki/List_comprehensions Comparison of list comprehensions on rosettacode.org] [[Category:Programming language comparisons|*List comprehension]] [[Category:Articles with example C Sharp code]] [[Category:Articles with example Haskell code]] [[Category:Articles with example Lisp code]] [[Category:Articles with example Python code]] [[Category:Articles with example Racket code]] [[fr:Compréhension de liste]] [[pt:List comprehension]]

revision.text:
{{Underlinked|date=September 2016}}
In [[Catalan mythology]], '''Comte Estruch'''—whose real name was either Arnald Estruc or Wilfred Estruch—was a 12th-century Catalan wealthy noble.
==Legend==
The legend says that King [[Alfonso II of Aragon]] sent the old noble Count Arnald Estruc to fight paganism and witchcraft at Llers Castle (Alt Emporda) where the Count was killed in 1173. Having led an un-Christian life, after his death the Count become a demonic being. Count Estruch sucked blood from the villagers in the area and seduced and impregnated young women. After nine months, these women would give birth to monstrous newborns who were dead at birth.
Conde Estruch terrorized the villagers for several years until finally the monster was found and killed by an elderly nun. Other versions say that a hermit of Jewish origin that made the Count rest using ancient rituals associated with [[Kabbalah]]. The castle was destroyed during the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939). This legend is the oldest [[vampire]] tale in European history and is one of the few Spanish myths associated with [[vampirism]].
==Adaptations== This legend was popularized in the novels of Salvador Sainz (Estruch, El cine Dracula), and in a few short stories by the same author (Les filles d'Estruc, L'hote d'Estruc, Strigoiaca, L'anneau d'Estruc, Les caves Marcia....).
==References==
* ''Dossier Vampirismo'' de Tali Carreto Revista Freek, Cádiz (20 de febrero de 2006) * ''El gran libro de los vampiros'' de Angel Gordon, Morales y Torres editores. * ''Vampiros, mito y realidad de los no-muertos''de Miguel C. Aracil, Editorial Edaf, S.A. * ''Vampiros: magia póstuma dentro y fuera de España'' de Jordi Ardanuy. Barcelona, Luna Negra, 1994. * Salvador Sáinz : Estruch, 1991. * Salvador Sáinz : El cine de Dracula, 2007.
==External links== * [http://blocs.gracianet.cat/lelefant_trompeta/2011/09/26/els-origens-de-el-comte-estruch/ Origenes del Conde Estruc | L'elefant Trompeta]
[[Category:Vampires]] [[Category:Catalan mythology]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{For|the station formerly at Eastern Parkway & Snediker Avenue|Eastern Parkway (BMT Fulton Street Line)}} {{Infobox NYCS | name = Eastern Parkway–
 Brooklyn Museum | image = Eastern Parkway-Brooklyn Museum IRT Eastern Parkway 7.JPG | image_caption = Manhattan-bound platform | bg_color = #E20F00 | address = Washington Avenue & Eastern Parkway
Brooklyn, NY 11238 | borough = [[Brooklyn]] | locale = [[Prospect Heights, Brooklyn|Prospect Heights]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.671622|N|73.96275|W|display=inline,title}} | lat_dir = N | lon_dir = W | division = IRT | line = [[IRT Eastern Parkway Line]] | service = Eastern west local | service_header = Eastern west local header | connection = | code = 341 | platforms = 2 [[side platform]]s | tracks = 4 (2 on each level) | structure = Underground | open_date = {{start date and age|1920|10|10}} | wifi = yes | passengers = 1,530,635{{NYCS const|riderref}} | pass_year = 2017 | pass_percent = -3.4 | rank = 301 | accessible = future | acc_note = | next_north = {{NYCS next | station=Grand Army Plaza | line=IRT Eastern Parkway Line | service=Eastern west local}} | next_south = {{NYCS next | station=Franklin Avenue | line=IRT Eastern Parkway Line | service=Eastern west local}} | legend = {{NYCS infobox legend|allexceptnights}}{{NYCS infobox legend|alltimes}}{{NYCS infobox legend|nightsonly}} }} '''Eastern Parkway–Brooklyn Museum''' is a local [[metro station|station]] on the [[IRT Eastern Parkway Line]] of the [[New York City Subway]]. Located at the intersection of Washington Avenue and Eastern Parkway in [[Brooklyn]] adjacent to the [[Brooklyn Museum]], it is served by the '''[[2 (New York City Subway service)|2]]''' at all times, the '''[[3 (New York City Subway service)|3]]''' at all times except late nights, and the '''[[4 (New York City Subway service)|4]]''' train during late nights. == History == {{stack|float=right| {{NYCS 2-tracked side platform station |1=Grand Army Plaza |l1=Grand Army Plz |2=Franklin Avenue |l2=Franklin Av |code=IRT Eastern Parkway Line |color=red |textcolor=white |deg=075 }} }} The name of the station was originally intended to be "Institute Park". However, the IRT received a petition from Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences to change the name of the station to "Brooklyn Museum" to provide an adequate guide for the station's location. As a result an order was issued on March 3, 1920, changing the name of the station to "Eastern Parkway–Brooklyn Museum".{{cite news |title=Station Name Changed After Public Hearing |url=http://fultonhistory.com/highlighter/highlight-for-xml?altUrl=http%3A%2F%2Ffultonhistory.com%2FNewspaper%252014%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201920%2FBrooklyn%2520NY%2520Standard%2520Union%25201920%2520-%25201964.pdf|via=fultonhistory.com |accessdate=July 4, 2018 |work=The Brooklyn Standard Union |date=March 4, 1920 |page=11}} The signs and tiles had to be finished as the station finish work was already underway.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iyM0AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA116&dq=canarsie+line+construction+elevated+evergreen+branch&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO9IPOj_bZAhVRdt8KHXTjDq0Q6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=canarsie%20line%20construction%20elevated%20evergreen%20branch&f=false|title=Annual Report ...|last=Commission|first=New York (State) Transit|date=1922|publisher=J.B. Lyon Company|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=131|language=en}} On October 10, 1920, three stations that were not ready to be opened with the rest of the line, at [[Bergen Street (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Bergen Street]], [[Grand Army Plaza (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Grand Army Plaza]] and Eastern Parkway–Brooklyn Museum, were opened.{{cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1920/10/11/103481051.pdf|title=Subway Stations Opened: Last Three in Eastern Parkway Branch of I.R.T. Put Into Service|date=October 11, 1920|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=December 20, 2015}} During the 1964–1965 fiscal year, the platforms at Eastern Parkway, along with those at four other stations on the Eastern Parkway Line, were lengthened to 525 feet to accommodate a ten-car train of 51-foot IRT cars.{{Cite book|title=Annual Report 1964–1965|last=|first=|publisher=New York City Transit Authority|year=1965|isbn=|location=|pages=|via=}} In 2002, it was announced that Eastern Parkway would be one of ten subway stations citywide to receive renovations.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/boroughs/renovation-set-10-subway-stations-article-1.485558|title=Renovation Is Set for 10 Subway Stations|last=|first=|date=June 11, 2002|work=NY Daily News|access-date=January 8, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} As part of the 2015–2019 MTA Capital Program, elevators will be added to the platforms and street, which would make the station fully compliant with accessibility guidelines under the [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990]].{{cite web|title=MTA Capital Program 2015-2019: Renew. Enhance. Expand.|url=http://web.mta.info/capital/pdf/CapitalProgram2015-19_WEB%20v4%20FINAL_small.pdf|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=October 28, 2015|date=October 28, 2015|page=61}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mta.info/news/2018/04/26/funding-subway-station-ada-accessibility-approved|title=Funding For Subway Station ADA-Accessibility Approved|last=|first=|date=April 26, 2018|website=www.mta.info|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 27, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/news/pdf/MTA_2017_Preliminary_Budget_July_Financial_Plan_2017_2020_Volume_2.pdf|title=MTA 2017 Preliminary Budget July Financial Plan 2017 –2020 Volume 2|last=|first=|date=July 2016|website=mta.info|publisher=Metropolitan Transportation Authority|access-date=August 6, 2016}} A contract for the elevators' construction was awarded in August 2018, and substantial completion is projected for October 2020.{{Cite web|url=http://web.mta.info/mta/news/books/pdf/181113_1400_CPOC.pdf|title=Capital Program Oversight Committee Meeting November 2018|date=November 13, 2018|accessdate=November 10, 2018|page=90|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]}} == Station layout == {|table border=0 cellspacing=0 cellpadding=3 |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''G''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Street Level |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=400 valign=top|Exit/Entrance |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=50 valign=top|'''B1''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=100 valign=top|Mezzanine |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;" width=400 valign=top|Fare control, station agent |- |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 rowspan=4 valign=top|'''B2''' |style="border-top:solid 1px gray;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;border-bottom:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|[[Side platform]], doors will open on the right |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=100|'''Northbound local''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=400|← {{rint|newyork|2}} toward [[Wakefield–241st Street (IRT White Plains Road Line)|Wakefield–241st Street]] ([[Grand Army Plaza (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Grand Army Plaza]])
← {{rint|newyork|3}} toward [[Harlem–148th Street (IRT Lenox Avenue Line)|Harlem–148th Street]] ({{rint|newyork|4}} toward [[Woodlawn (IRT Jerome Avenue Line)|Woodlawn]] late nights) (Grand Army Plaza) |- |'''Southbound local''' |→ {{rint|newyork|2}} toward [[Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College (IRT Nostrand Avenue Line)|Flatbush Avenue–Brooklyn College]] ([[Franklin Avenue (IRT Eastern Parkway Line)|Franklin Avenue]]) →
→ {{rint|newyork|3}} ({{rint|newyork|4}} late nights) toward [[New Lots Avenue (IRT New Lots Line)|New Lots Avenue]] (Franklin Avenue) → |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;border-top:solid 2px black;border-right:solid 2px black;border-left:solid 2px black;text-align:center;" colspan=2|[[Side platform]], doors will open on the right |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=50 rowspan=2 valign=top|'''B3''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=100|'''Northbound express''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;" width=400|← {{rint|newyork|4}} {{rint|newyork|5}} do not stop here |- |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|'''Southbound express''' |style="border-bottom:solid 1px gray;"|→ {{rint|newyork|4}} {{rint|newyork|5}} do not stop here → |} There are two local tracks with two [[side platform]]s. The express tracks pass underneath the station and are not visible from the platforms.[http://www.nycsubway.org/lines/irt-brooklyn-map2.html Brooklyn IRT: Map 2, Brooklyn IRT Dual Contracts] A large mosaic displays [[Eastern Parkway]] and ''Brooklyn Museum''. In the eastern [[mezzanine (architecture)|mezzanine]] are architectural [[Ornament (art)|ornaments]] from the Brooklyn Museum collection, installed during the 2003 renovation of the station.{{cite web|title=Steinberg Family Sculpture Garden|url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/exhibitions/sculpture_garden|website=Brooklyn Museum|accessdate=October 20, 2017}} The platforms and the eastern mezzanine formerly displayed abstract art paintings created in 1991 by artist [[Pat Steir]], collectively called the ''Brueghel Series''.[http://www.nycsubway.org/perl/stations?215:3116 Brooklyn IRT: Eastern Parkway/Brooklyn Museum] There is an emergency exit from the express level at the south end of each platform. There is an unused western mezzanine containing [[turnstile]]s and a token booth with a door hidden in the tiles; the entrance to this mezzanine has been removed on street level. ===Exits=== The only two exits to this station are from the east mezzanine:{{cite web|title=MTA Neighborhood Maps: Park Slope/Prospect Park|url=http://web.mta.info/maps/neighborhoods/bkn/B3_Park_Slope_2015.pdf|website=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority|mta.info]]|publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]]|accessdate=August 2, 2015|date=2015}} * Eastern Parkway, south side in front of Brooklyn Museum * Eastern Parkway, north side mall across the street from Brooklyn Museum == Image gallery {{unreferenced|date=January 2009}} The '''Facit catalog''' is a specialized postage [[stamp catalog]] for the countries of [[Scandinavia]]. First published in 1947, it is the most detailed and complete catalog available for philatelists interested in the stamps of [[Denmark]], [[Faroes]], [[Finland]], [[Iceland]], [[Norway]], [[Sweden]], [[Greenland]], [[Åland]], and the [[Danish West Indies]]. Although published in Sweden, the language of the catalog is now English.
Catalog content is developed by a committee of 20 leading philatelists. Beginning with the 2007 catalog, and following a trend among catalog publishers, images of the stamps are printed in color.
Specific recent versions of the catalog include: * ''FACIT 2007 Special'' (2007) - includes all countries, and a handbook section with informative articles * ''FACIT Postal VII'' (2004) - [[postal history]] and [[postmark]]s of Sweden * ''FACIT Sverige 2005'' (2005) - nonspecialized catalog for Sweden only * ''FACIT Special Classic'' (2018) - includes all countries with varieties and specialties up to 1951.
The catalogs are published by '''Facit Förlag AB''', located in [[Västerås]], Sweden.
== External links == * [http://www.facit.se/index_eng.html English homepage of Facit Förlag AB]
[[Category:Philately of Greenland]] [[Category:Philately of Sweden]] [[Category:Philately of Denmark]] [[Category:Philately of Norway]] [[Category:Philately of the Faroe Islands]] [[Category:Philately of Iceland]] [[Category:Stamp catalogs]]

{{Use Harvard referencing|date=December 2017}} {{italic title}} {{hatnote|For "fāngyán" in the general sense of a regional dialect, see [[Varieties of Chinese]].}} {{Infobox Chinese |title=''Fangyan'' |c=方言 |l="Regional Speech" |p= Fāngyán |w=Fang1-yen2 |mi={{IPAc-cmn|f|ang|1|.|yan|2}} |gr=Fangyan |j=Fong1-jin4 |y=Fōng-yìhn |tl=Hong-giân |oc-bs=*{{IPA|paŋ ŋa[r]}} }} [[File:Han dialect groups map.svg|thumb|right|Major Han-period dialect groups inferred from the ''Fangyan'']] The '''''Fāngyán''''' ({{zh|c=方言}}; “regional words”,[[David R. Knechtges]], Taiping Chang (eds.): ''Ancient and Early Medieval Chinese Literature. A Reference Guide''. Part Three. Leiden/Boston: Brill, 2014; p. 1935. “regional expressions”,Xinzhong Yao (ed.): ''The Encyclopedia of Confucianism''. Routledge, 2015; p. 472. “dictionary of local expressions”,[[Joseph Needham]], Colin A. Ronan (eds.): ''The Shorter Science and Civilisation in China''. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1978; p.&npbs;118. “regional spoken words”;Timothy Michael O’Neill: ''Ideography and Chinese Language Theory: A History''. Berlin/Boston: de Gruyter, 2016; p. 206. not “dialects” as in modern Chinese“[I]t is ... disingenuous to translate ''fangyan'' as “dialect” in classical Chinese sources,” op. cit. p. 207.) was the first [[Chinese dictionary]] of dialectal terms. It was edited by the scholar [[Yang Xiong (author)|Yang Xiong]], who lived from 53 BC to 18 AD. The full title is ''Yóuxuān shǐzhĕ juédài yǔ shì biéguó fāngyán'' (輶軒使者絕代語釋別國方言) "Local expressions of other countries in times immemorial explained by the Light-Carriage Messenger," which alludes to a [[Zhou dynasty]] tradition of imperial emissaries who made annual surveys of regional vocabulary throughout China. Yang's preface explains that he spent 27 years collating and editing the ''Fangyan'', which has some 9000 characters in 13 chapters (卷). ''Fangyan'' definitions typically list regional synonyms. For instance, chapter 8, which catalogs animal names, gives regional words for ''hu'' (虎 "tiger") in Han times.
(虎, 陳魏宋楚之間或謂之李父, 江淮南楚之間謂之李耳, 或謂之於菟. 自關東西或謂之伯都.) "Tiger: in the regions of Chen-Wei Song-Chu [Central China], some call it ''lifu''; in the regions of Jiang-Huai Nan-Chu [Southern China], they call it ''li'er'', and some call it ''wutu''. From the Pass, east- and west-ward [Eastern and Western China], some call it also ''bodu''." (adapted from Serruys 1967: 256)
Comparative linguists have used dialect data from the ''Fangyan'' in reconstructing the pronunciation of [[Eastern Han Chinese]] (1st century CE), which is an important diachronic stage between [[Old Chinese]] and [[Middle Chinese]]. In the above example, [[Paul Serruys]] reconstructs "tiger" as Old Chinese *''blxâg''. Serruys also applied the techniques of modern [[dialectology]] to the distribution of regional words, identifying dialect areas and their relationships. ==See also== *''[[Shuowen Jiezi]]'' *[[List of Chinese dictionaries]] ==References== *DeFrancis, John. 1984. ''The Chinese Language: Fact and Fantasy''. University of Hawaii Press. *Groves, Julie M. 2008. [http://sino-platonic.org/complete/spp179_cantonese.pdf "Language or Dialect – or Topolect? A Comparison of the Attitudes of Hong Kongers and Mainland Chinese towards the Status of Cantonese"], ''Sino-Platonic Papers'' 179:1–103. *Mair, Victor H. 1991. [http://sino-platonic.org/complete/spp029_chinese_dialect.pdf "What Is a Chinese "Dialect/Topolect"? Reflections on Some Key Sino-English Linguistic terms"], ''Sino-Platonic Papers'' 29:1–31. *[[Paul Serruys|Serruys, Paul L-M.]] 1959. ''The Chinese Dialects of Han Time According to'' Fang Yen. Berkeley: University of California Press. *Serruys, Paul L-M. 1967. "Five Word Studies on ''Fang Yen'' (Third Part): The Dialect Words for 'Tiger'." ''Monumenta Serica'' '''26''', 255–285. {{doi|10.1080/02549948.1967.11744969}} ==External links== {{wikisourcelang|zh|方言|''Fang Yan'' (in Chinese)}} * [http://www.chinaknowledge.de/Literature/Science/fangyan.html ''Fangyan'' 方言], Chinaknowledge * [http://ctext.org/fang-yan/zh 方言], text in Chinese at CText * [https://books.google.com/books?id=kIUsAAAAYAAJ 方言: 13卷 (粤東書局) 1873] on Google Books * [https://archive.org/search.php?query=%E6%96%B9%E8%A8%80 方言] at the Internet Archive == Footnotes == {{Dictionaries of Chinese}} [[Category:Chinese classic texts]] [[Category:Chinese dictionaries]] [[Category:Han dynasty texts]] [[Category:1st-century books]]
