{{Infobox museum | name = Rockefeller Museum | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Photo of the Latin inscription set against the Rockefeller Museum, seat of the Israel Antiquities Authority in Jerusalem (15714219522).jpg | imagesize = 250 | caption = Rockefeller Museum, Jerusalem | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = | established = 13 January 1938 (opening date) | dissolved = | location = 27 Sultan Suleiman Street, East Jerusalem | type = Archaeology museum | collection = | visitors = | director = | president = | curator = Fawzi Ibrahim | publictransit = | car_park = | network = | website = [https://www.imj.org.il/en/wings/archaeology/rockefeller-archaeological-museum Rockefeller Archaeological Museum] }} [[File:Founding of the Rockefeller Museum.jpg|thumb|Laying of the [[cornerstone]], 19 June 1930]]
The '''Rockefeller Museum''', formerly the '''Palestine Archaeological Museum''' (PAM),<ref>{{cite web |last=Baruch |first=Yuval |title=Historic Background |url= http://www.antiquities.org.il/article_Item_eng.asp?sec_id=39&subj_id=156&id=155&module_id=12#as |work=Rockefeller Museum – The Museum and its Exhibitions |publisher=Israel Antiquities Authority |author2=Rachel Kudish-Vashdi }}</ref> is an [[archaeology]] [[museum]] located in [[East Jerusalem]]<ref name=rm>{{cite web |title=Rockefeller Archaeological Museum |url=http://www.english.imjnet.org.il/htmls/page_1684.aspx?c0=15160&bsp=14162 |publisher=[[The Israel Museum]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729084713/http://www.english.imjnet.org.il/htmls/page_1684.aspx?c0=15160&bsp=14162 |archivedate=2012-07-29 |df= }}</ref> that houses a large collection of artifacts unearthed in the excavations conducted in [[Mandate Palestine]], in the 1920s and 1930s.
The museum is under the management of the [[Israel Museum]] and houses the head office of the [[Israel Antiquities Authority]].<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/culture/travel/the-rockefeller-museum-1.242644 The Rockefeller Museum, [[Haaretz]]]</ref>
==History== Prior to the establishment of the Rockefeller Museum, the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandate]] [[Department of Antiquities of Mandatory Palestine|Department of Antiquities]] and British School of Archaeology were housed in an old building in Jerusalem with a small exhibition hall. The only other archaeological museum at the time was the Franciscan Biblical Museum, built in 1902.<ref name="antiquities.org.il">[http://www.antiquities.org.il/article_Item_eng.asp?sec_id=39&subj_id=156&id=155&module_id=12#as Rockefeller Museum: Historic Background]</ref>
In 1906, the [[Jewish National Fund]] began to negotiate the purchase of Karm el-Sheikh, a tract of land facing the northeastern corner of the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]] walls, to house the [[Bezalel Academy of Art and Design|Bezalel School of Art and Crafts]]. The founder of the school, [[Boris Schatz]] envisaged a museum and university that would overlook the [[Temple Mount]].<ref name="imj.org.il">[http://www.imj.org.il/rockefeller/eng/index.html West Meets East: The Story of Rockefeller Museum]</ref> In 1919, town planner [[Patrick Geddes]] proposed the establishment of an antiquities museum at this site. To further the project, the Mandate authorities proposed a special tourism tax in 1924.<ref name="antiquities.org.il"/>
Visiting [[Mandatory Palestine|Palestine]] in 1925, during the days of the British Mandate, [[James Henry Breasted]], founder and director of the [[University of Chicago]]'s Oriental Institute, recognized the need for an archaeological museum in Jerusalem to house important regional finds.<ref>[http://www.antiquities.org.il/article_Item_eng.asp?sec_id=39&subj_id=156&Module_id=12 Israel Antiquities Authority: Rockefeller Museum]</ref> Encouraged by [[Lord Plumer]], the British [[High Commissioner]], Breasted approached American philanthropist [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]], who agreed to donate two million dollars toward the project. Previously, he had offered to build an archeological museum in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kletter |first1=Raz |title=Just Past? The Making of Israeli archaeology |date=2006 |publisher=Equinox Publishing Limited |location=London/Oakville |p=174 |isbn=1-84553-085-3}}</ref> but he was turned down, possibly due to pressure from the British government, which was anxious to keep America from establishing a foothold in the region.
[[File:East Jerusalem, the Rockefeller Museum Rockefeller Museum P1190104.JPG|thumb|Relief representing [[Israelite]] culture, one of ten bas-reliefs by [[Eric Gill]] in the inner courtyard at the museum.]] The museum was designed by [[Austen Harrison]], (Austen St. Barbe Harrison), chief architect of the Mandatory Department of Public Works, who drew up blueprints for a white limestone building integrating eastern and western architectural elements.<ref name="kletter">{{cite journal | first=Raz | last=Kletter | title=The Friends of Antiquities: The story of an Israeli volunteer group and comparative remarks | journal=[[Journal of Hebrew Scriptures]] | volume=8 | at = Article 2}}</ref> The cornerstone of the new museum was laid on June 19, 1930, but construction was delayed due to the discovery of tombs dating to the fifth century B.C. at the building site.<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/arts/in-jerusalem-a-museum-s-treasures-go-unseen.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm | title=In Jerusalem, a Museum's Treasures Go Unseen | newspaper=[[New York Times]] | date=27 September 1990 }}</ref> The museum features a stone [[bas-relief]] of the meeting of [[Asia]] and [[Africa]] above the main entrance together with ten stone reliefs illustrating different cultures and a [[gargoyle]] fountain in the inner courtyard carved in 1934 by the British sculptor [[Eric Gill]] (1882–1940).<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.imj.org.il/rockefeller/eng/Gill.html | title=Eric Gill, 1882–1940 | publisher=[[Israel Museum]] | work=East Meets West: The Story of the Rockefeller Museum | accessdate=31 January 2016 }}</ref> Gill also produced stone carved [[signage]] throughout the museum in [[English language|English]], [[Hebrew]], and [[Arabic]].
[[File:Rockefeller Museum.jpg|thumb|Rockefeller Museum inner courtyard.]] [[File:Rockefeller_Museum_Courtyard.jpg|thumb|Inner courtyard with a view to the tower.]] The museum opened to the public on January 13, 1938. Officially, it was called the ''Palestine Archaeological Museum'', but was also known as the ''Rockefeller Museum''.<ref name="kletter" /> Until the final days of the Mandate period, the museum was administered by the British Palestine Government.<ref name=PP>{{cite news | newspaper=[[Palestine Post]] | date = April 22, 1948 | title = Board of Trustees for Museum | page = 3}}</ref> On 1 April 1948 it was closed for the public.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kletter |first1=Raz |title=Just Past? The Making of Israeli archaeology |date=2006 |publisher=Equinox Publishing Limited |location=London/Oakville |p=175 |isbn=1-84553-085-3}}</ref>
On 20 April 1948, the High Commissioner appointed a council of international trustees to administer the museum. The council consisted of twelve members: two representing the High Commissioner, one from the British Academy, one from the British Museum, one from the French National Academy, one from the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, two from the Antiquities Departments of the Egyptian, Syrian, Lebanese, Iraqi or Transjordanian governments; one from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]], one from the Royal Swedish Academy, one from the American Institute of Archaeology, and one from the American School of Oriental Research in Jerusalem.<ref name=PP/><ref>[http://www.antiquities.org.il/article_Item_eng.asp?sec_id=39&subj_id=156&Module_id=12 Rockefeller Museum, Israel Antiquities Authority]</ref> The board run the museum until 1966. In the 1950s controversies came up about objects removed by the two sides to Amman and the Israeli side respectively.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Kletter |first1=Raz |title=Just Past? The Making of Israeli archaeology |date=2006 |publisher=Equinox Publishing Limited |location=London/Oakville |pp=185–189 |isbn=1-84553-085-3}}</ref>
After the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]], the museum also became a secondary headquarters of the Jordanian Department of Antiquities, headed by [[Gerald Lankester Harding]] until 1956.<ref name=Silberman>{{cite book| last=Silberman | first=Neil Asher | title=The archaeology of Israel: constructing the past, interpreting the present|year=1997|publisher=[[Sheffield Academic Press]] |isbn=978-1-85075-650-7|pages=72|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jH4MkEQH7M8C&pg=PA72|authorlink=Neil Asher Silberman |editor1-first=Neil Asher | editor1-last=Silberman | editor2-first=David B. | editor2-last=Small | chapter=Structuring the Past}}</ref> In 1966, the museum was nationalized by [[King Hussein]] during the [[Jordanian annexation of the West Bank]].<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
Seven months later, when the 1967 [[Six-Day War]] broke out, the museum was captured by an Israeli paratroop brigade.<ref name="nytimes.com"/> Its hexagonal tower was used as a lookout. Fierce fighting took place here between Israeli and Jordanian forces, culminating in an Israeli victory.{{Citation needed| date=May 2012}} The Museum was then officially renamed as the Rockefeller Museum.<ref>{{cite book| first=Kimberly | last=Katz | page=134 | publisher =[[University Press of Florida]] | title=Jordanian Jerusalem: Holy Places and National Spaces | year=2005 }}</ref>
Since 1967, the museum has been jointly managed by the Israel Museum and the Israel Department of Antiquities and Museums (later reorganized as the [[Israel Antiquities Authority]]).
Inside what was to have been the rear courtyard of the museum stood (until it died after nearly 300 years in 1998) one of the oldest pine trees in the country. According to Arab legend, on the site of this pine tree, [[Ezra the Scribe]] sat and wrote the Torah for Israel.<ref name="Vilnay1973">{{cite book|author=Zev Vilnay|title=Legends of Jerusalem|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Vi7XAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=24 November 2010|date=May 1973|publisher=Jewish Publication Society of America|isbn=978-0-8276-0004-1|page=224}}</ref> The stump may still be seen behind the museum.
==Collections==
The museum's first curator was John H. Iliffe,<ref>{{cite web|title=J H Iliffe Collection|url=http://www.library.uq.edu.au/fryer/ms/uqfl514.pdf|accessdate=4 December 2014}}</ref> who arranged the artifacts in chronological order, from two million years ago to 1700 AD. Among the museum's prized possessions are 8th-century wooden panels from the [[al-Aqsa Mosque]] and 12th-century ([[Crusade]]r-period) marble lintels from the [[Church of the Holy Sepulchre]]. Most of the collection consists of finds from the 1920s and 1930s.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1990/09/27/arts/in-jerusalem-a-museum-s-treasures-go-unseen.html In Jerusalem, a Museum's Treasures Go Unseen]</ref> On display are artifacts unearthed in [[Jerusalem]], [[Megiddo (place)|Megiddo]], [[Ashkelon]], [[Lachish]], [[Samaria]], and [[Jericho]]. One of the [[Lachish letters]] is on permanent display at the museum,<ref>[http://cojs.org/cojswiki/Lakhish_Ostraca,_c._587_BCE Lakhish Ostraca, c. 587 BCE] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111022237/http://cojs.org/cojswiki/Lakhish_Ostraca,_c._587_BCE |date=2012-11-11 }}</ref> as are the statuary and stucco decorations from the [[Umayyad]] [[Hisham's Palace]].
Some of the [[Dead Sea Scrolls]] discovered at [[Qumran]] between 1947 and 1956, consisting of Jewish texts and commentaries, were housed in the Rockefeller Museum.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
In 1967, following the Israeli capture of East Jerusalem, the scrolls were seized by Israel and relocated to the [[Shrine of the Book]], a specially designed building on the grounds of the Israel Museum, with the ownership of these scrolls having been heavily contested ever since. The [[Copper Scroll]] was taken to the Jordan Archaeological Museum in Amman.<ref>[http://www.bibleinterp.com/opeds/curious.shtml On the Curious Protests of the Dead Sea Scrolls Exhibition in Toronto]</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *''Memoirs'', David Rockefeller, New York: [[Random House]], 2002.
==External links== {{commons category|Rockefeller Museum}} * [http://www.imj.org.il/en/node/154 Rockefeller Archaeological Museum Homepage]

'''''S v Motau and Another''''' is an important case in [[South African law]]. It was heard in the [[Transvaal Province|Transvaal]] Provincial Division on March 11, 1963, with judgment handed down on March 25. The judges were Ludorf J en Trollip J.
== Judgment == The case was an appeal from a conviction on a charge of [[arson]], which requires [[South_African_criminal_law#Arson|by definition]] that the affected [[property]] be [[immovable property|immovable]]. As it appeared that the state had failed to prove sufficiently that the complainant's "house" was immovable, the court substituted a conviction of [[malicious injury to property]], although the appellants had been acquitted on such a charge.
== See also == * [[Arson]] * [[Crime in South Africa]] * [[Law of South Africa]] * [[South African criminal law]] * [[South African property law]]
== References == === Case law === * ''[[S v Motau and Another]]'' 1963 (2) SA 521 (T).

page.title: Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture

revision.text:
{{Infobox library | library_name = Schomburg Center
for Research in Black Culture | image = NYPL Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.jpg | image_size = 325px | country = [[United States]] | type = [[Research library]] | established = 1905 (as the ''135th Street Branch'')
1925 (as the ''Division of Negro Literature, History and Prints'') | items_collected=poems by [[Phillis Wheatley]], papers of [[Ralph Bunche]], [[Malcolm X]], and [[Hiram Rhodes Revels]] | collection_size=10 M | req_to_access= None | budget= | director = [[Kevin Young (poet)|Kevin Young]] | website = [http://www.nypl.org/locations/schomburg Official website] {{Infobox NRHP | embed = yes | name = Schomburg Center
for Research in Black Culture | image = NYPL Former 135th Street Branch, Manhattan.jpg | image_size = 325px | caption = (2009) | nrhp_type = nhl | location = 103 West 135th Street
[[Manhattan]], [[New York City]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|48|51|N|73|56|27|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | architect = [[Charles Follen McKim]] | architecture = [[Renaissance Revival architecture|Italian Renaissance Palazzo]] | added = September 21, 1978 |designated_nrhp_type = December 23, 2016 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | refnum = 78001881 | mpsub = | governing_body = | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = February 3, 1981 | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_number = | designated_other2_color = #ffe978 }}}} The '''Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture''' is a [[research library]] of the [[New York Public Library]] (NYPL) and an archive repository for information on people of African descent worldwide. Located at 515 [[Lenox Avenue|Malcolm X Boulevard]] (Lenox Avenue) between [[135th Street (Manhattan)|West 135th]] and [[136th Street (Manhattan)|136th]] Streets in the [[Harlem]] neighborhood of [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], it has, almost from its inception, been an integral part of the Harlem community. It is named for Afro-Puerto Rican scholar [[Arturo Alfonso Schomburg]]. The resources of the Center are broken up into five divisions, the Art and Artifacts Division, the Jean Blackwell Hutson General Research and Reference Division, the Manuscripts, Archives and Rare Books Division, the Moving Image and Recorded Sound Division, and the Photographs and Prints Division. In addition to research services, the center hosts readings, discussions, art exhibitions, and theatrical events. It is open to the general public. == Early history== ===135th Street branch=== In 1901, [[Andrew Carnegie]] tentatively agreed to donate $5,200,000 ({{Inflation|US|5,200,000|1901|r=-2|fmt=eq}}) to construct 65 [[Carnegie library|branch libraries]] in [[New York City]], with the requirement that the City provide the land and maintain the buildings once construction was complete.{{cite news |title=Carnegie Offers City Big Gift |date=1901-03-16 |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1901-03-16/ed-1/seq-1/ |work=[[New-York Tribune]] |pages=1–2}} Later in 1901 Carnegie formally signed a contract with the City of New York to transfer his donation to the city to then allow it to justify purchasing the land to house the libraries.{{cite news |title=Library Plans All Right Now: Carnegie Approves Controller Coler Contracts |date=1901-09-09 |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030193/1901-09-09/ed-1/seq-3/ |work=The Evening World |pages=3}}; [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1901-09-10/ed-1/seq-6/ Carnegie Approves the Contracts], [http://www.search.proquest.com/docview/96155738 Mr. Carnegie's Libraries], ''The New York Times'', 1901-09-10. [[McKim, Mead & White]] were chosen as the architects and [[Charles Follen McKim]] designed the three-story library building at 103 West 135th Street in the Italian Renaissance Palazzo mode.{{harvp|White|Willensky|2000|p=507}}; contra: These attribute the original design to [[Stanford White]]: [http://search.proquest.com/docview/146891492 "Books, Black Culture and- the Course of History: Books and History"], ''Washington Post'', and [https://www.webcitation.org/64e5rRBgD?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/arts/road-to-freedom-show-at-library.html "'Road to Freedom' Show at Library".] At its opening on July 14, 1905, the library had 10,000 books{{cite news |title=Library's West 135th Street Branch Will Mark 25th Anniversary Tuesday: Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature Brought Harlem Unit 'to Attention of Book World--Considered Finest |date=1930-07-30 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226222291 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=3}} and the librarian in charge was Gertrude Cohen.{{cite news |title=New Library Opened |date=1905-07-15 |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1905-07-15/ed-1/seq-4/ |work=New-York Tribune |page=4}} ===Rose tenure (1920–42) === [[File:Books-are-Weapons-Poster.jpg|left|thumb|200px|World War II-era [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] poster promoting use of the Schomburg Collection of the New York Public Library ([[Federal Art Project]] 1941–43)]] In 1920, [[Ernestine Rose (librarian)|Ernestine Rose]], a white woman born in [[Bridgehampton, New York|Bridgehampton]] in 1880, became the branch librarian.{{harvp|Tibbets|pp=9, 18}} She quickly integrated the all-white library staff.{{harvp|Tibbets|pp=20-21}} [[Catherine Allen Latimer]], the first [[African-American]] librarian hired by the NYPL, was sent to work with Rose as was Roberta Bosely months later.{{harvp|Sinnette|1989|pp=132-133}} Some time later [[Sadie Peterson Delaney]] became employed at the branch.{{cite book |last1=Jordan |first1=Casper LeRoy |title=Handbook of Black Librarianship |chapter=African American Forerunners in Librarianship |edition=2 |editors=E. J. Josey and Marva L. DeLoach |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2000 |location=Lanham, MD |page=31}} Together, they created a plan to assist integrating reading into the lives of the library attendees and cooperated with schools and social organizations in the community. In 1921, the library hosted the first exhibition of African-American art in Harlem; it became an annual event.{{harvp|Wintz|2007|pp=38-39}} The library became a focal point to the burgeoning [[Harlem Renaissance]]. In 1923, the 135th Street branch was the only branch in New York City employing Negroes as librarians,{{cite journal |title=Work With Negroes Round Table |journal=Bulletin of the American Library Association |date=July 1922 |first=Ernestine |last=Rose |volume=16 |issue=4 |pages=361–366 |id= |jstor=25686069}} and consequently when [[Regina M. Anderson]] was hired by the NYPL, she was sent to work at the 135th Street branch.{{cite web|last1=Giaimo|first1=Cara|title=The Librarian at the Nexus of the Harlem Renaissance|url=https://www.atlasobscura.com/articles/harlem-renaissance-librarian-regina-anderson|website=Atlas Obscura-Stories|publisher=Atlas Obscura|accessdate=March 21, 2018|date=March 21, 2018}}{{harvp|Whitmire|2007|p=409}} Rose issued a report to the [[American Library Association]], in 1923, which stated that requests for books about Negroes or written by Negroes had been increasing,{{cite news |title=Interest Increases In Negro Literature: Miss Ernestine Rose Does Not Believe in Purely Colored Libraries |date=1923-05-02 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226214352 |work=[[New York Amsterdam News]] |page=7}} and that the demand for professionally trained colored librarians was also.Marshall: 67; cf. [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25686069 Working with Negroes Roundtable by Ernestine Rose] In late 1924, Rose called a meeting, with attendees including [[Arturo Alfonso Schomburg]], [[James Weldon Johnson]], [[Hubert Harrison]], that decided to focus on preserving rare books, and solicit donations to enhance its African-American collection.{{harvp|Tibbets|1995|pp=21-22}} On May 8, 1925, it began operating as the ''Division of Negro Literature, History and Prints'', a division of the NYPL.{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Anekwe |title=Schomburg Center, historic property |date=1978-11-04 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226445221 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=A11}}; cf. Tibbets: 22, [http://search.proquest.com/docview/226316940 "Historical Society is Launched at Library", 1925-05-13], {{harvp|Sinnette|1989|p=134}} In 1926, Schomburg was interested in selling his collection of African-American literature because he wanted it to be available to the general public,{{harvp|Sinnette|1989|p=141}} but he wanted the collection to stay in Harlem.{{harvp|Sinnette|1989|p=136}} Rose and the National Urban League convinced the Carnegie Foundation to pay $10,000 to Schomburg and then donate the books to the library. In 1926, the center's collection won acclaim with the addition of Schomburg's personal collection. By donating his collection, Schomburg sought to show that black people had a history and a culture and thus were not inferior to other races.{{cite news |first=Felicia R. |last=Lee |title=Harlem Center’s Director to Retire in Early 2011 |date=2010-04-19 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/19/arts/19library.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64efq0YEF?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/19/arts/19library.html?scp=1&sq=Schomburg&st=cse |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}; cf. [http://search.proquest.com/docview/226427674 Rare Library Brought to Harlem: Schomburg's Rare Negro Library Now at the 135th Street Branch Noted Bibliophile Began Collecting Books on His Race 35 Years Ago] About 5,000 objects in Schomburg's collection were donated.{{cite news |title=Mrs. Latimer in Charge of Negro History Department: Ass't Librarian |date=1927-01-26 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226371429 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=9}}; "2,932 volumes, 1,124 pamphlets, and many valuable prints" cf; {{harvp|Sinnette|1989|p=141}} (''New York Library Bulletin'' 31, April 1927, p. 295). In 1929, Anderson was desirous of a promotion and enlisted the help of [[W. E. B. Du Bois]] and [[Walter Francis White]] when she was being discriminated against by not being promoted. After letters of intervention on her behalf by Du Bois and White, and a boycott of the library by White, Anderson was promoted and transferred to the Rivington Street branch of the NYPL.Whitmire: ? By 1930, the Center had 18,000 volumes. In 1932, Schomburg became the first curator of his collection, until his death in 1938.{{cite news |title=Schomburg is Buried While Crowds Mourn: Famous Curator Dead at 64; Collected Rare Books, Prints |date=1938-06-18 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226160559 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=1}} cf. [http://www.nypl.org/locations/schomburg/about/history Schomburg Center History.] In 1935, the Center developed a project to deliver books once a week to those handicapped severely enough that they could not make it to the library.{{cite news |first=Thelma |last=Berlack-Boozer |title=Shut-Ins Cheered By Books From Library: Special Service for Them Operated Only At Busy Branch in West 135th |date=1938-06-18 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226161624 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=8}} Dr. [[Lawrence D. Reddick]] became the second curator of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature.{{cite news |title=Curator of Negro Literature |date=1929-08-23 |url=http://www.search.proquest.com/docview/102836697 |work=New York Times |pages=24}} "Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick has been appointed curator of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature at the 135th Street Branch of the New York Public Library." At the behest of Reddick, in October 1940, the entire Division of Negro History, Literature and Prints was renamed the Schomburg Collection of Negro History and Literature.{{harvp|Sinnette|1989|p=193}} In 1942 Rose retired{{harvp|Tibbets|1995|p=27}} after an extension was built onto the rear of the building, at a time when the library had 40,000 books. Dorothy Robinson Homer replaced her as Branch Librarian, after the Citizen's Committee of the 135th Street Branch Library specifically requested a Negro to replace Rose.{{cite news |title=New Librarian Takes Over At Harlem Branch: Mrs. Dorothy R. Homer, 10 Years on Job, Gets Top Spot at 135th St. |date=1942-06-27 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226089714 |work=New York Amsterdam News |pages=4}} ===Countee Cullen branch=== After the extension was built, the library became known as the Countee Cullen Library,{{cite news |title=Miss Rhodes [sic, Ernestine Rose] Dies; Integrated Library |date=1961-04-16 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/225451240 |work=New York Amsterdam News |pages=4}} and the 135th Street Library is still considered the original location of the Countee Cullen library by the New York Public Library,{{cite web |url=http://www.nypl.org/locations/tid/19/about |title=About the Countee Cullen Library |accessdate=2012-01-19 |year=2012 |publisher=The New York Public Library |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64o2N5LcL?url=http://www.nypl.org/locations/tid/19/about |archivedate=2012-01-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} although that name is now only used for the extension itself on West 136th Street.Andrew L. Yarrow, [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/08/19/nyregion/repository-of-black-past-is-reopened.html "Repository of Black Past is Reopened"], ''The New York Times'', August 19, 1990 (archived). Homers created a room of books just for young adults and created the [[American Negro Theatre]] in the basement that spawned the play [[Anna Lucasta (play)|Anna Lucasta]], which was moved to Broadway. She kept the emphasis on building a community center for art, music and drama. She put on art exhibits that favored unknown, young artists of all races.{{cite news |first=Charles |last=Courtney |title=Library Tradition Carried On By Dynamic Little Lady: She Heads Popular Uptown Library Branch Civic-Minded |date=1944-12-30 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226038138 |work=New York Amsterdam News |pages=5A}} After the outbreak of WWII, Homer started a program of monthly concert recitals in the auditorium to enhance public spirit, but the demand by performers and audience members to continue the practice made it permanent.{{cite news |title=Doris Earle and Sallee Smith Set For Joint Recital |date=1946-02-09 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/225928025 |work=New York Amsterdam News |page=18}} ===Hutson tenure (1948–80) === In 1948, Jean Blackwell, later [[Jean Blackwell Hutson]], was named the director of the Center.{{cite journal |title=Jean Blackwell Hutson, ex-Chief of Schomburg Center, dies |journal=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |date=1998-02-23 |volume=93 |issue=13 |page=17 |id= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VMQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=jean+blackwell+hutson&source=bl&ots=_6JjTtG6N-&sig=yzUTilaRSkJe36SwqnhTXrBqLkw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=qcYBT5qkG8bs0gHNwJmADg&ved=0CHEQ6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=jean%20blackwell%20hutson&f=false |accessdate=2012-01-02}} In a 1966 speech, Hutson warned of the perilous status of the Schomburg collection.{{harvp|Dodson|Moore|Yancy|2000|pp=319-320}} In 1971, the Center began being supported by the privately funded Schomburg Corporation.{{cite news |title=Schomburg Center Opens in New York |date=1980-10-11 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tSkmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Sv4FAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=6299%2C1405282 |work=[[Afro-American (newspaper)|The Afro American]] |page=13 |accessdate=2012-01-02}} The next year, funds by New York City were allocated to renovate the building at 103 West 135th,{{cite news |title=Recalling the Early Days at the Schomburg Center, a Harlem Cultural Hub (page 1 of 2) |date=1987-08-29 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/arts/recalling-the-early-days-at-the-schomburg-center-a-harlem-cultural-hub.html?src=pm |work=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64emlWPBq?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/arts/recalling-the-early-days-at-the-schomburg-center-a-harlem-cultural-hub.html?src=pm |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }} and it was renamed the building of the ''Schomburg Collection for Research in Black Culture''.{{cite news |title=Recalling the Early Days at the Schomburg Center, a Harlem Cultural Hub (page 2 of 2) |date=1987-08-29 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/arts/recalling-the-early-days-at-the-schomburg-center-a-harlem-cultural-hub.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm |work=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64eu4DMID?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/29/arts/recalling-the-early-days-at-the-schomburg-center-a-harlem-cultural-hub.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}; cf. [http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/81-SCHOMBURG.pdf NYC Landmarks Preservation Committee.] Simultaneously, the entire Schomburg collection was rounded up from various branch libraries and transferred to the Center.{{harvp|Dodson|Moore|Yancy|2000|p=354}} In 1972, it was designated as one of NYPL's research libraries. In 1973, a building on the west side of Lenox ave between 135th and 136th was bought so that it could be demolished and a new building could be constructed. The location was chosen due to its proximity to other community agencies and because it was the "scene of the Harlem Renaissance."{{harvp|Henderson|1974|p=78}} In 1978, the building on 135th Street between Lenox and 7th Avenues was entered into the [[National Register of Historic Places]].{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Anekwe |title=Schomburg Center, historic property |date=1978-11-04 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/226445221 |work=New York Amsterdam News |pages=A11 |accessdate=2011-12-31}}; cf. [http://search.proquest.com/docview/146891492 Stein Lauds Hudson.] In 1979, it was formally listed in the NRHP.{{cite news |first=C. Gerald |last=Fraser |title=Schomburg Unit Listed as Landmark: Spawning Ground of Talent 40 Seats Are Not Enough Plans for a Museum |date=1979-04-01 |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/120941139 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2011-12-31}} ==Schomburg Center== [[File:Schomburg-center.jpg|thumb|right|287px|The entrance to the Center]] In 1980, a new Schomburg Center was founded at 515 [[Lenox Avenue]]. In 1981, the original building on West 135th Street which held the Schomburg Collection was designated a New York City Landmark. In 2016, both the original and current buildings, now joined by a connector, were designated a [[National Historic Landmark]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nps.gov/nhl/news/LC/spring2016/SchomburgCtrBlackCulture.pdf |title=Draft NHL nomination for Schomburg Center |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=2017-03-10}} ===Wray tenure (1981–1983) === In 1981, Wendell L. Wray became the director of the Center.{{cite news |title=The City; Schomburg Center Loses Its Chief |date=1983-03-10 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/10/nyregion/the-city-schomburg-center-loses-its-chief.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64emWXOz9?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/10/nyregion/the-city-schomburg-center-loses-its-chief.html |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Protests began over Wray's decision to not hire an African-American man to head the Center's Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Books Division and instead hired Robert Morris.{{cite news |title=The City; 2 Black Activists Seized in Protest |date=1982-11-19 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/nyregion/the-city-2-black-activists-seized-in-protest.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-02 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64en47rEm?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/nyregion/the-city-2-black-activists-seized-in-protest.html |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}; cf. [https://www.webcitation.org/64emWXOz9?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/10/nyregion/the-city-schomburg-center-loses-its-chief.html] In 1983, Wray resigned to pursue academic research and Catherine Hooker was named acting director.{{cite news |first=Susan Heller |last=Anderson |author2=Mauricel |title=New York Day by Day |date=1984-01-13 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/01/13/nyregion/new-york-day-by-day-174899.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-02}} ===Dodson tenure (1984–2011)=== [[Howard Dodson]] became the director in 1984, at a time when the Schomburg was primarily a cultural center visited by tourists and schoolchildren and its research facilities were known only to scholars. In 1984, the Schomburg's collection was at 5 million. In 1984 attendance was 40,000 a year.{{cite news |first=Felicia R. |last=Lee |title=Historian Will Direct Schomburg Center in Harlem |date=2010-11-17 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/18/arts/18director.html# |work=New York Times |accessdate=2012-01-13 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/64efITAkK?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/18/arts/18director.html |archivedate=2012-01-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }} As early as 1984, the Schomburg was recognized as the most important institution in the world for collections of art and literature of people in Africa or its diaspora.{{cite news |title=Harlem Renaissance Exhibit Set Saturday at State Museum |date=1984-02-01 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cQ4hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=G3QFAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=2456%2C43736 |work=[[The Daily Gazette|Schenectady Gazette]] |page=10}} In 1983, a scholars-in-residence program started at the center.{{Cite web |title=Schomburg Center Scholars-in-Residence Program |url=http://www.nypl.org/help/about-nypl/fellowships-institutes/schomburg-center-scholars-in-residency |website=The New York Public Library|access-date = 2016-01-18}} In 1986, an exhibit entitled ''Give me your poor...'' sparked controversy.{{cite news |title='Liberty' Gala Perplexes Black Patriots |date=1986-06-25 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wbhaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8VkDAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=4976%2C2605568 |work=[[Tampa Bay Times|The St. Petersburg Evening Independent]] |page=13A}} In March 1987, a public funding campaign was started to raise money to renovate the old library and to enhance the new Center's housing and its functions.{{cite news |first=Michel |last=Marriott |title=Schomburg Center Acts to Halt Loss of Black History |date=1987-11-23 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/11/23/nyregion/schomburg-center-acts-to-halt-loss-of-black-history.html?src=pm |work=The New York Times}}; [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ATAtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6r0EAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=2775%2C8088858 Culture Center Expansion.] In 1991, completion of additions to the Schomburg Center were completed. The new center on Malcolm X was expanded to include an auditorium and a connection to the old landmark building on 135th.[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/04/08/nyregion/grand-opening-of-expanded-schomburg-center.html "Grand Opening of Expanded Schomburg Center"], ''The New York Times'', April 8, 1991 (archived). The ''Art and Artifacts Division'' and the ''Moving Image and Recorded Sound Division'' were moved into the old landmark building.{{cite news |title=Research Complex Expanded |date=1991-04-20 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dS9DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=VK0MAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=2561%2C2917879 |work=[[The Albany Herald]] |page=8A}} In 2000, the Schomburg Center held an exhibition titled "Lest We Forget: The Triumph Over Slavery", which later went on tour around the world for more than a decade under the sponsorship of [[UNESCO]]'s [[The Slave Route Project|Slave Route Project]]. In 2005, the center held an exhibition of letters, photographs and other material related to Malcolm X. In 2007, the building was renovated and expanded in an $11 million project. The Schomburg Center had 120,000 visitors a year; by 2010, Dodson announced he would retire in early 2011. In 2007, the Schomburg Center was one of the sponsors of the [[African Burial Ground National Monument]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/afbg/upload/Dedication%20Flyer%20and%20Events%20edited.pdf |title=Memorial Dedication: African Burial Ground National Monument |accessdate=2012-01-14}} ===Muhammad tenure (2011–2016)=== {{external media| float = right| video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?85044-1/tour-schomburg-center Tour of the Schomburg Center conducted by Khalil Gibran Muhammad, May 27, 2015], [[C-SPAN]]}} Following Howard Dodson's announcement of his retirement in 2010, [[Khalil Gibran Muhammad]], great-grandson of [[Elijah Muhammad]] and professor of history at [[Indiana University]], was announced as Dodson's replacement. In the summer of 2011, Muhammad became the fifth director of the Schomburg. His stated goals were for the Schomburg to be a focal point for young adults and to collaborate with the local community, to not only reinforce its pride, but also for the Center to be a gateway for revealing the history of Black people worldwide.{{cite news |first=Cyril Josh |last=Barker |title=New director of Schomburg Center gets his feet wet |date=2011-09-15 |url=http://www.amsterdamnews.com/news/local/article_56a90284-df21-11e0-abe1-001cc4c002e0.html?cbst=57 |work=New York Amsterdam News |accessdate=2012-01-02}} In July, the Center began an exhibit of Malcolm X footage and prints entitled ''Malcolm X: the Search for Truth''. ===Young tenure (2016–present)=== On August 1, 2016, the New York Public Library announced that poet and academic [[Kevin Young (poet)|Kevin Young]] would begin as the Director in the "late fall" of 2016.{{cite news |last=Kelly |first=William P. |date=August 1, 2016 |title=Introducing the New Director of the Schomburg Center, Kevin Young |url=https://www.nypl.org/blog/2016/08/01/schomburg-director-kevin-young |newspaper=NYPL blog |location=|access-date= August 1, 2016}} [[File:Bob Gore photographs Kevin Young and Claudia Rankin.jpg|thumb|Bob Gore photographs Kevin Young and Claudia Rankin]] ==Collection== [[File:NYPL Schomburg logo.jpg|thumb|NYPL Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture logo]] The Schomburg Collection was considered, in 1998, as consisting of the rarest, and most useful, [[Afrocentrism|Afrocentric]] artifacts of any public library in the United States.{{cite book |last1=Goedeken |first1=Edward A. |title=Untold Stories: Civil Rights, Libraries and Black Librarianship |chapter=The Founding and Prevalence of African-American Social Libraries & Historical Societies, 1828-1918 |editors=John Mark Tucker |publisher=University of Illinois |year=1998 |location=Champaign, IL |pages=38 |isbn=0-87845-104-8}} At least as late of 2006, it is viewed as the most prestigious for African-American materials in the country.{{cite news |first=Elaine |last=Woo |title=A Champion of Black History |date=2006-10-21 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/oct/21/local/me-clayton21 |work=Los Angeles Times}} As of 2010, the Collection stood at 10 million objects, The Center contains a signed, first edition of a book of poems by [[Phillis Wheatley]], archival material of [[Melville J. Herskovits]],[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/21226 "Melville J. and Frances S. Herskovits papers"], New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. [[John Henrik Clarke]],[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20834 "John Henrik Clarke papers"], New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. [[Lorraine Hansberry]],[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20931 "Lorraine Hansberry papers"], Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library. [[Malcolm X]] and [[Nat King Cole]]. The collection includes the files, or papers of the [[International Labor Defense]], the [[Civil Rights Congress]], the [[Symphony of the New World]],{{cite web|title=Symphony of the New World: 50th Anniversary of a Pioneering Organization|publisher=[[New York Public Library]]|url=https://www.nypl.org/blog/2014/08/06/symphony-new-world-50th-anniversary|access-date=2018-07-12}} and the [[National Negro Congress]]. It also includes the papers of [[Lawrence Brown (pianist)|Lawrence Brown]] (1893-1973),[http://www.nypl.org/sites/default/files/archivalcollections/pdf/mg38.pdf "Lawrence Brown Papers"] at Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library. [[Ralph Bunche]], [[Léon Damas]], [[William Pickens]],[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20809 "William Pickens papers"], Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. [[Hiram Rhodes Revels]], [[Clarence Cameron White]]. The files of the [[South Africa]]n [[Dennis Brutus]] Defense Committee (restricted).[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20822 "Dennis Brutus Papers"], Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. The collection also includes manuscripts of [[Alexander Crummell]][http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20572 "Alexander Crummell Papers"], Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. and [[John Edward Bruce]], manuscripts of [[Slavery]], [[Abolitionism in the United States|Abolitionism]] and on the [[Caribbean|West Indies]], and letters and unpublished manuscripts of [[Langston Hughes]]. It includes some papers from [[Christian Fleetwood]], [[Paul Robeson]] (restricted),[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20649 "Paul Robeson collection, 1925-1956"] Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. [[Booker T. Washington]],[http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20789 "Booker T. Washington correspondence, 1889-1913"], Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library Archives & Manuscripts. and Schomburg himself. It includes musical recordings, black and jazz periodicals, rare books and pamphlets, and tens of thousands of art objects. {{cite book |last1=Kaiser |first1=Ernest |title=Handbook of Black Librarianship |chapter=Library Holdings on African Americans |edition=2 |editors=E. J. Josey and Marva L. DeLoach |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2000 |location=Lanham, MD |pages=259–261}} The Center's collection includes documents signed by [[Toussaint Louverture]] and a rare recording of a speech by [[Marcus Garvey]]. ==See also== {{Portal|African American}} * [[Moorland–Spingarn Research Center]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|30em}} '''Sources''' {{refbegin|30em}} * [http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/uhic/ReferenceDetailsPage/ReferenceDetailsWindow?displayGroupName=Reference&jsid=&disableHighlighting=false&userGroupName=nypl&prodId=UHIC&action=e&windowstate=normal&catId=&documentId=GALE|K1606003299&mode=view Howard Dodson, Jr. (Scholars in Residence Program)] * {{cite book |last1=Dodson |first1=Howard |last2=Moore |first2=Christopher |last3=Yancy |first3=Roberta |title=The Black New Yorkers : the Schomburg illustrated chronology |publisher=John Wiley |year=2000 |location=New York |isbn=0-471-29714-3 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Henderson |first1=James W. |title=The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture Its Condition, Operation, and Needs |publisher=New York Public Library |year=1974 |location=New York |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Josey |first1=E. J. |authorlink1=E. J. Josey |last2=DeLoach |first2=Marva L. |title=Handbook of Black Librarianship |publisher=Scarecrow Press |year=2000 |location=Lanham |isbn=0-8108-3720-X}} * {{cite book |last1=Marshall |first1=A. P. |title=A Century of Service |chapter=Service to Afro-Americans |editors=Sidney L. Jackson, Elanor B. Herling, and E. J. Josey |publisher=American Library Association |year=1976 |location=Chicago |pages=62–78 |isbn=0-8389-0220-0}} * {{cite book |last1=Sinnette |first1=Elinor Des Verney |title=Arthur Alfonso Schomburg, Black Bibliophile & Collector A Biography |publisher=The New York Public Library & Wayne State University Press |year=1989 |location=Detroit |isbn=0-8143-2156-9 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Tibbets |first1=Celeste |title=Ernestine Rose and the Origins of the Schomburg Center |publisher=Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture |year=1995 |location=New York |isbn=0-87104-419-6 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=White |first1=Norval |authorlink1=Norval White |last2=Willensky |first2=Elliot |title=AIA Guide to New York City |publisher=Crown Publishers |year=2000 |location=New York |page=507 |isbn=0-8129-3106-8 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |title=Breaking the Color Barrier: Regina Andrews and the New York Public Library |journal=Libraries and the Cultural Record |year=2007 |first=Ethelene |last=Whitmire |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=409–421,459. |id= |url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/222598496 |accessdate=2012-01-12 |doi=10.1353/lac.2007.0068 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Wintz |first1=Cary D. |title=Harlem Speaks: A Living History of the Harlem Renaissance |publisher=Sourcebooks |year=2007 |location=Naperville |isbn=978-1-4022-0436-4 |ref=harv}} {{refend}} '''Reference books''' {{refbegin|30em}} * Harris, Michael H., and Donald G. Davis Jr (1978). ''American Library History: a bibliography''. Austin: University of Texas. {{ISBN|0-292-70332-5}} * Davis, Donald G. Jr, and John Mark Tucker (1989). ''American Library History: a comprehensive guide to the literature''. Santa Barbara: ABC-CLIO, Inc. {{ISBN|0-87436-142-7}} {{refend}} '''Further reading''' {{refbegin|30em}} * [http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1901-12-18/ed-1/seq-7/;words=Gertrude+Cohen?date1=1900&rows=20&searchType=basic&state=New+York&date2=1904&proxtext=Gertrude+AND+Cohen&y=13&x=4&dateFilterType=yearRange&index=0 Library Work in Schools 1901-12-18] * [http://search.proquest.com/docview/103926399 Gift To Public Library, ''The New York Times'', 1926-05-26; exact date of the official transfer to the New York Public Library by the Carnegie Foundation at the behest of the National Urban League and Rose] * [http://search.proquest.com/docview/105429294 Books--Authors. ''The New York Times'', 1940-07-26: Description of the donation by Schomburg to the Library in 1926] * [http://search.proquest.com/docview/226222964 Schomburg Collection Bulwark VS Propaganda, 1940] * [http://search.proquest.com/docview/22600151 "Harlem Wants Library Named For Schomburg: Late Bibliophile Gave Impetus to Move Establishing Unit" (1942)] * Eleanor Blau, [https://www.nytimes.com/1985/02/01/arts/weekender-guide.html "Friday A FIENDISH OPENING"], ''The New York Times'', Weekender Guide, February 1, 1985 (archived). * John Jacob, [https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VXwlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Z_UFAAAAIBAJ&dq=schomburg%20center&pg=2303%2C510219 "Black History Month"], ''Washington Afro-American'', February 2, 1988. * [http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fullresult=true&recordid=0 Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture (not digitized yet)] * {{cite journal |title='The Place to Go': The 135th Street Branch Library and the Harlem Renaissance |journal=The Library Quarterly |date=Oct 2003 |first=Sarah A. |last=Anderson |volume=73 |issue=4 |pages=383–421 |id= |jstor=4309684 |doi=10.1086/603439}} * {{cite book |last1=Wilson |first1=Sondra Katherine |title=The Crisis Reader: Stories, Poetry, and Essays from the N.A.A.C.P.'s Crisis Magazine |publisher=Modern Library |year=1999 |location=New York |isbn=0375752315}} * {{cite book |last1=Wilson |first1=Sondra Katherine |title=The Opportunity Reader: Stories, Poetry, and Essays from the Urban League's Opportunity Magazine |publisher=Modern Library |year=1999 |location=New York |isbn=0375753796}} * {{cite book |last1=Wilson |first1=Sondra Katherine |title=The Messenger Reader: Stories, Poetry, and Essays from The Messenger Magazine |publisher=Modern Library |year=2000 |location=New York |isbn=037575539X}} * Girardi, Pamela (2005). ''The American Historical Association's Guide to Historical Literature''. {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category multi|Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture|NYPL former 135th Street Branch}} *[http://www.nypl.org/locations/schomburg Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture] - official site at NY Public Library * [https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/beta/partner/schomburg-center-for-research-in-black-culture Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, The New York Public Library at Google Cultural Institute] *[http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/169204-1 "Writings of Hughes and Hurston", broadcast from the Schomburg Center] from [[C-SPAN]]'s ''[[American Writers: A Journey Through History|American Writers]]'' {{New York City Historic Sites}} {{National Register of Historic Places in New York}} {{authority control}} [[Category:African-American arts organizations]] [[Category:African-American culture]] [[Category:African-American studies organizations]] [[Category:Archives in the United States]] [[Category:Harlem]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Libraries on the National Register of Historic Places in Manhattan]] [[Category:Libraries in Manhattan]] [[Category:Library buildings completed in 1905]] [[Category:National Historic Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:New York Public Library]] [[Category:Photo archives]] [[Category:Special collections libraries]]

{{Expand Japanese|topic=vg|しゃべる!DSお料理ナビ|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox video game |title = Shaberu! DS Oryōri Navi |image = Shaberudsoryorinavi boxart.PNG |developer = [[indieszero]] |publisher = [[Nintendo]], [[Sharp Corporation]] |designer = |engine = |composer = Toshiyuki Sudo |released = {{vgrelease|JP|July 20, 2006}} |genre = [[Edutainment]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Nintendo DS]] }}
{{nihongo|'''''Shaberu! DS Oryōri Navi'''''|しゃべる!DSお料理ナビ|Shaberu! Dīesu Oryōri Nabi|literally "''It Talks! DS Cooking Navigator''"}} is a cooking simulator for the [[Nintendo DS]]. It was released on July 20, 2006 in Japan.
==Brief information== The software contains numerous Japanese recipes with step by step instructions, and the user can use the Nintendo DS's microphone for voice-recognition commands like turning pages. All the instructions are read out loud, while some instructions are video recordings showing how to do some tasks like chopping. It is possible to choose recipes based on a number of calories, the ingredients the user has and so forth. The simulator also keeps in memory what dishes the player has already made. It also features a timer, useful when on is cooking noodles and the like; however, some kitchen appliances already have built-in timers, like [[kitchen stove]]s and [[microwave oven]]s for example. As a bonus, the [[Game & Watch]] game, ''Chef'', can also be played in this DS title.
==Reception== ''Shaberu! DS Oryōri Navi'' received an Excellence Prize for Entertainment at the 2006 [[Japan Media Arts Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://plaza.bunka.go.jp/english/festival/2006/entertainment/000499/index.php|title=2006 Japan Media Arts Festival Entertainment Division Excellence Prize Shaberu! DS Oryouri Navi|publisher=[[Japan Media Arts Festival|Japan Media Arts Plaza]]|accessdate=2010-06-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426034809/http://plaza.bunka.go.jp/english/festival/2006/entertainment/000499/index.php|archivedate=2010-04-26|df=}}</ref>
==Sequels and Spinoffs== ''Shaberu! DS Oryōri Navi'' gave birth to five sequels, with development split between Nintendo and [[Koei]]. Nintendo itself issued a Japan only sequel {{nihongo|[https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ds/aoij/index.html ''Kenkou Ouen Recipe 1000: DS Kondate Zenshuu'']|[[:ja:健康応援レシピ1000 DS献立全集|健康応援レシピ1000 DS献立全集]]|lit. "Health Boost Recipe 1000: DS Complete Menu"}} and the North America-only 2010 release ''America's Test Kitchen: Let's Get Cooking'', based on the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] program, [[America's Test Kitchen]] after ''[[Cook's Illustrated]]'' magazine helped the publisher to write the game.<ref>[https://www.nintendo.com/games/detail/fIeyCqi4iFZwJXW395q2KhDE0wyfId_q America's Test Kitchen: Let's Get Cooking] Nintendo of America, Inc.</ref>
[[Koei]]'s releases are both Japan only, with the company releasing {{nihongo|[http://www.gamecity.ne.jp/ds/cook/ ''Shaberu! DS Oryōri Navi: Marugoto Teikoku Hotel'']|しゃべる!DSお料理ナビ まるごと帝国ホテル|It Talks! DS Cooking Navigator: The Marugoto Empire Hotel}} and {{nihongo|[http://www.gamecity.ne.jp/ds/sweets/ ''Kantan! Tanoshii! Okashi Navi DS'']|かんたん!たのしい!お菓子ナビDS|Simple! Fun! Pastry Navigator DS}}.
==Legacy== A musical remix based on this Nintendo DS title was used in ''[[Super Smash Bros. Brawl]]'', where it was heard in the Kirby Final Smash update. This was only heard on the Japanese version of the official website;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.smashbros.com/jp/characters/kirby.html |title=カービィ：最後の切りふだ |accessdate=2007-12-07 |last=Sakurai |first=Masahiro |date=2007-10-09 |work=スマブラ拳!! }}</ref> however, the song was added to all versions of Super Smash Bros. Brawl as one of the songs for the [[PictoChat]] stage.

{{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Smithsonian–Roosevelt African Expedition |Image_Name = Smithsonian Institution Archives - SIA2009-1371.jpg |Imagesize = 300 |Image_Alt = |Image_Caption = Participants in the expedition. [[Smithsonian Institution Archives]] |Thumb_Time = |AKA = |Participants = [[Theodore Roosevelt]];
R. J. Cunninghame;
[[Frederick Selous]];
[[Kermit Roosevelt]];
[[Edgar Alexander Mearns]];
[[Edmund Heller]];
[[John Alden Loring]]. |Location = |Date = 1909–10 |nongregorian = |Deaths = |Result = |URL = }} The '''Smithsonian–Roosevelt African Expedition''' was an expedition to Africa led by outgoing American president [[Theodore Roosevelt]] and outfitted by the [[Smithsonian Institution]].{{cite journal|journal=Science|title=President Roosevelt's African Trip|date=December 18, 1908|volume=28|issue=729|pages=876–877|jstor=1635075|doi=10.1126/science.28.729.876|pmid=17743798}} Its purpose was to collect specimens for the Smithsonian's new Natural History museum, now known as the [[National Museum of Natural History]]. The expedition collected around 11,400 animal specimens which took Smithsonian naturalists eight years to catalog.{{cite web |url=http://www.mnh.si.edu/onehundredyears/expeditions/SI-Roosevelt_Expedition.html |title=Smithsonian-Roosevelt African Expedition |website=National Museum of Natural History: Celebrating 100 Years |publisher=Smithsonian Institution, National Museum of Natural History |accessdate=20 June 2013}} Following the expedition, Roosevelt chronicled it in his book ''African Game Trails''. ==Participants and resources== The group, led by the legendary hunter-tracker R. J. Cunninghame, included scientists from the Smithsonian and was joined from time to time by [[Frederick Selous]], the famous big game hunter and explorer. Among other items, Roosevelt brought with him four tons of salt for preserving animal hides, a lucky rabbit's foot given to him by boxer [[John L. Sullivan]], a [[Holland & Holland]] [[double rifle]] in [[.500/450 Nitro Express|.500/450]] donated by a group of 56 admiring Britons, a [[Winchester 1895]] rifle in [[.405 Winchester]], an Army ([[M1903 Springfield|M1903]]) Springfield in [[.30-06 Springfield|.30-06]] caliber stocked and sighted for him, a Fox No. 12 shotgun, and the famous Pigskin Library, a collection of classics bound in pig leather and transported in a single reinforced trunk. Participants on the Expedition included Roosevelt's son, [[Kermit Roosevelt|Kermit]], [[Edgar Alexander Mearns]], [[Edmund Heller]], and [[John Alden Loring]]. ==Timeline and route == [[File:Roosevelt-Smithsonian_Expedition_Map.jpg|left|thumb|Map of the route taken by the party. From the Edmund Heller Papers, [[Smithsonian Institution Archives]].|253x253px]]The party set sail from New York City on the steamer Hamburg on March 23, 1909, shortly after the end of Roosevelt's presidency on March 4. The party landed in [[Mombasa]], [[British East Africa]] (now [[Kenya]]), traveled to the [[Belgian Congo]] (now [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]) before following the [[Nile]] to [[Khartoum]] in modern [[Sudan]]. Financed by [[Andrew Carnegie]] and by his own proposed writings, Roosevelt's party hunted for specimens for the [[Smithsonian Institution]] and for the [[American Museum of Natural History]] in New York.{{cite web|title=Roosevelt African Expedition Collects for SI|url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_193|publisher=[[Smithsonian Institution Archives]]|accessdate=10 April 2012}} ==Results== Roosevelt and his companions killed or trapped approximately 11,397 animals. According to Theodore Roosevelt’s own tally, the figure included about four thousand birds, two thousand reptiles and amphibians, five hundred fish, and 4,897 mammals (other sources put this figure at 5,103). Add to this marine, land and freshwater shells, crabs, beetles and other invertebrates, not to mention several thousand plants, and the number of natural history specimens totals 23,151. A separate collection was made of ethnographic objects. The material took eight years to catalogue. The larger animals shot by Theodore and Kermit Roosevelt are listed on pages 457 to 459 of his book'' African Game Trails''. The total is 512, of which 43 are birds. The number of [[big-game hunting|big game]] animals killed, was 17 lion, 3 leopard, 7 cheetah, 9 hyena, 11 elephant, 10 buffalo, 11 (now very rare) black rhino and 9 [[White Rhinoceros|White rhino]]. Most of the 469 larger non big game mammals included 37 species and subspecies of antelopes. The expedition consumed 262 of the animals which were required to provide fresh meat for the large number of porters employed to service the expedition. Tons of salted animals and their skins were shipped to [[Washington, D.C.]]; the quantity took years to [[taxidermy|mount]], and the Smithsonian shared many duplicate animals with other [[museum]]s. Regarding the large number of animals taken, Roosevelt said, "I can be condemned only if the existence of the [[National Museum of Natural History|National Museum]], the [[American Museum of Natural History]], and all similar zoological institutions are to be condemned."O'Toole, Patricia (2005) ''When Trumpets Call'', p. 67, Simon and Schuster, {{ISBN|0-684-86477-0}} In assessing whether the toll of animals was excessive in that the animals taken spanned a period of ten months, and were procured over an area that ranged from Mombasa through Kenya, to Uganda and the Southern Sudan, a distance travelled, with side trips, of several thousand kilometres. The diversity of larger mammal species collected was such that few individuals of any species were shot in any given area, and the large mammals collected had a negligible impact on the great herds of game that roamed East Africa at that time. Apologists for the Roosevelts have pointed out that the number of each big game species shot was very modest by the standards of the time: many white hunters of that period, for example, such as [[Karamoja Bell]], had killed over 1,000 elephants each, while the Roosevelts between them killed just eleven. In making this comparison it has to be remembered that the white hunters weren’t collecting specimens for museums, but were employed by landowners to clear animals from land they wanted to use for plantations. Although the safari was conducted in the name of science, it was as much a political and social event as it was a hunting excursion; Roosevelt interacted with renowned professional hunters and land-owning families, and met many native peoples and local leaders. Roosevelt became a Life Member of the [[National Rifle Association]], while President, in 1907 after paying a $25 fee.{{cite book|title=From my cold, dead hands: Charlton Heston and American politics|first=Emilie|last=Raymond|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|year=2006|page=246|isbn=978-0-8131-2408-7}} He later wrote a detailed account in the book ''African Game Trails'', where he describes the excitement of the chase, the people he met, and the [[flora]] and [[fauna]] he collected in the name of science.{{cite book|author=Theodore Roosevelt|title=African Game Trails: An Account of the African Wanderings of an American Hunter-naturalist. Illustrated|url=https://archive.org/details/africangametrail01roos|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=1910|publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons}} While Theodore Roosevelt greatly enjoyed hunting, he was also an avid conservationist. In ''African Game Trails'' he condemns "game butchery as objectionable as any form of wanton cruelty and barbarity" (although he does note that "to protest against all hunting of game is a sign of softness of head, not of soundness of heart") and as a pioneer of wilderness conservation in the USA he fully supported the British Government's attempts at that time to set aside wilderness areas as game reserves, some of the first on the African continent. He notes (page 17) that "in the creation of the great game reserve through which the Uganda railway runs the British Government has conferred a boon upon mankind", a conservation attitude which Roosevelt helped sow that finally grew and blossomed in the form of the great game parks of East Africa today. ==Further reading== * [http://www.theodoreroosevelt.com TheodoreRoosevelt.com's account of the trip and review of African Game Trails with photos] *{{cite book|author=John Alden Loring|title=African adventure stories|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_DYPAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=21 June 2013|year=1914|publisher=C. Scribner's sons}} * [http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/tr.htm On Safari With Theodore Roosevelt, 1909] from [http://www.eyewitnesstohistory.com/index.html Eye Witness to History.com] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Theodore Roosevelt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smithsonian-Roosevelt African Expedition}} [[Category:Theodore Roosevelt]] [[Category:1909 in science]] [[Category:1910 in science]] [[Category:1909 in Africa]] [[Category:1910 in Africa]] [[Category:Expeditions from the United States]] [[Category:Smithsonian Institution]] [[Category:African expeditions]]

The '''Syrbotae''', a species of giant mentioned in many medieval [[Bestiary|bestiaries]], were said to live in Africa and stand about eight cubits tall (a cubit is the distance from a man's elbow to the tip of his middle finger).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theoi.com/Phylos/Syrbotai.html|title=Syrbotae|accessdate=2008-12-28|work=[[Theoi Greek Mythology]]}}</ref>
Source: Pliny the Elder, Pliny's Natural History, Volumes 1–3, 160; Weber, Process of the seuyn Seuyn Sages, 327.
== References == <references />
[[Category:Medieval European legendary creatures]] [[Category:Giants]]
